White

questions.text: What is the most frequent side effect experienced by a 24-year-old woman of reproductive age who visited a rural primary healthcare center in India for the purpose of having an IUCD inserted to prevent pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Side effects of IUDs

Bleeding (Option D)
  • Most common side effect; physiological bleeding resolves in 1-3 months. Iron supplementation may be needed.
  • Persistent bleeding despite treatment may necessitate IUD removal.

Pain (Option C ruled out)

Frequently causes removal; managed with analgesics. Resolves in 3 months. Severe pain may indicate uterine perforation (rare).

Pelvic inflammatory disease (OptionB ruled out)

Certain organisms reach the uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries via the IUD thread. Presents with fever, abdominal pain, and discharge. Higher risk in women with multiple sexual partners. Requires broad-spectrum antibiotics; IUD removal if no improvement.

Uterine perforation

Rare complications linked to immediate postpartum insertion or poor technique. 1st generation IUDs are associated with a higher risk of pregnancy.

Failure of contraception ➜ pregnancy
  • Least pregnancies are reported with MIRENA.
  • If a woman requests an induced abortion – legally allowed.
  • If a woman wants to continue pregnancy and threads are visible:
    • Pull the thread and continue pregnancy.
    • Explain the risk of spontaneous abortion or congenital anomalies.
  • If a woman wants to continue pregnancy and threads are not visible:
    • Uterus examination for any complications
    • Evacuation of uterus if any complication is identified.

Ectopic pregnancy (OPTION A ruled out)

Recognized by lower abdominal pain, dark vaginal bleeding, or amenorrhea. Women at high risk should avoid IUDs.

Expulsion

Typically occurs within weeks of insertion or during menstruation; higher risk in young, nulliparous, postpartum women or using 1st generation IUDs

Migration of IUD

Rarely causes intestinal obstruction; diagnosed via X-ray imaging if suspected.

Stage

6-8 hours

questions.text: Which one of the following options does not meet the minimum standards for maintaining sanitation in schools and their surroundings in India?

options.label: B
options.text: Combined doors + windows area = 25% of floor space area

options.label: D
options.text: One urinal for 10 students and one latrine for 25 students

questions.correct_answer: D. One urinal for 10 students and one latrine for 25 students
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Location

Centrally situated with proper approach roads, away from busy places like roads, factories, and marketplaces. School premises should be fenced and hazard-free.

Site

High, well-drained land. 10 acres for higher elementary schools, 5 acres for primary schools, with additional 1 acre per 100 students.

Structure

Single-story buildings preferred. Exterior walls should be 10 inches thick and heat-resistant

Doors and windows
  • Combined door + window area = atleast 25% of floor area.
  • Cross ventilation should be present. (Option B ruled out)

Classroom

No more than 40 students per room. Minimum 10 sq. ft. per student. (Option C ruled out)

Color of Interior

White interior walls, periodically white-washed.

Furniture
  • Desks should be of ‘minus type’.
  • Chair with proper back rest. (Option A ruled out)

Lighting

Natural light from the left side, not from the front.

Water Supply

Independent source of safe, potable water, continuous supply distributed from taps.

Lavatory

One urinal per 60 students, one latrine per 100 students. Separate facilities for boys and girls. (Option D)

questions.explanation:
1.

End poverty everywhere in all its forms.

2.

Zero hunger- Achieve food security, improve nutrition, and promote sustainable agriculture.

3.

Ensure healthy lives and well-being for all ages.

4.

Provide inclusive and equitable quality education and lifelong learning opportunities.

5.

Achieve gender equality and empower women and girls.

6.

Ensure access to sustainable & clean water and sanitation for all.

7.

Ensure access to affordable, clean and modern energy for all.

8.

Promote sustainable economic growth, full employment, and decent work.

9.

Build resilient infrastructure, promote sustainable industrialization, and foster innovation.

10.

Reduce inequality within and among countries.

11.

Make cities and human settlements inclusive, safe, resilient, and sustainable

12.

Ensure sustainable consumption and production patterns.

13.

Take urgent action to combat climate change and its impacts.

14.

Conserve and sustainably use water bodies - oceans, seas, and marine resources.

15.

Protect, restore, and sustainably use terrestrial ecosystems and preserve biodiversity.

16.

Promote peaceful and inclusive societies, ensure access to justice, and build effective institutions.

17.

Strengthen global partnerships for sustainable development.

Target 3.1: Reduce maternal mortality

By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births (Option B ruled out)

Target 3.2: End all preventable deaths under five years of age

By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births (Option C) and under‑5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births (Option D ruled out)

Target 3.3: Fight communicable diseases

By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases (Option A ruled out)

Target 3.4: Reduce mortality from non-communicable diseases and promote mental health

By 2030, reduce by one-third premature mortality from non-communicable diseases through prevention and treatment and promote mental health and well-being

Target 3.5: Prevent and treat substance abuse

Strengthen the prevention and treatment of substance abuse, including narcotic drug abuse and harmful use of alcohol

Target 3.6: Reduce road injuries and deaths

By 2020, halve (50% less) the number of global deaths and injuries from road traffic accidents

Target 3.7: Universal access to sexual and reproductive care, family planning and education

By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programs

Target 3.8: Achieve universal health coverage

Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all

Target 3.9: Reduce illnesses and deaths from hazardous chemicals and pollution

By 2030, substantially reduce the number of deaths and illnesses from hazardous chemicals and air, water and soil pollution and contamination

questions.text: Jet black pigmentation of the tongue with tactile hallucinations is a feature of:
questions.explanation:
Cocaine

Category

Description

Source

Derived from the leaves of the coca plant (Erythroxylum coca).

Mechanism of Action
  • Inhibits presynaptic transporters of NE, DA, and 5-HT.
  • Blocks neurotransmitter reuptake, increasing synaptic levels and enhancing postsynaptic effects.

Methods of Use
  • Snorting: Inhalation through the nose; less dangerous than other methods.
  • Injection: Subcutaneous or intravenous; high risk of overdose, cardiac issues.
  • Smoking: Crack cocaine or freebasing; most dangerous, intense addiction and behavioural changes.
  • Oral Use: Rare and ineffective.

Combination Use

Cocaine + Heroin = "Speed Balls."

Intoxication Effects

Euphoria, hyperactivity, agitation, tachycardia, hypertension, dilated pupils, acute cardiovascular risks.

Adverse Effects

Hypertension, tachycardia, myocardial ischemia/infarction, seizures, arrhythmias, hyperthermia, paranoia.

Cocaine Withdrawal
  • Symptoms: Cravings, anhedonia, dysphoria, hypersomnia, irritability, increased appetite.
  • No physical complications (e.g., seizures).

Cocaine-Induced Psychosis
  • Paranoid delusions and hallucinations (auditory > tactile/visual).
  • Formication ("cocaine bugs").
  • More common in men and IV/crack cocaine users.

Treatment for Withdrawal
  • Supportive care for mood symptoms and suicidal ideation.
  • Behavioral interventions like CBT for relapse prevention.

Treatment for Psychosis

Short-term antipsychotics (e.g., haloperidol).

questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Propranolol

Use of propranolol

Drug of choice
  • Migraine prophylaxis
  • Essential tremors
  • Aortic dissection if they also have hypertension

Other Uses
  • Hypertension-second-line drugs
  • Stable angina
  • Cardiac arrhythmias
  • Congestive heart failure
  • Thyrotoxicosis
  • Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (Improve cardiac output).
  • Myocardial infarction (Ml): Secondary prophylaxis of Ml and myocardial salvage during evolution of Ml (decreases mortality).

Acute management of migraine attack

  • Triptans: Decrease the release of CGRP and cause vasoconstriction. E.g., Sumatriptan, Rizatriptan.
  • CGRP ligand blockers: Eptinezumab, Fremanezumab
  • CGRP receptor blockers: Rimegepant
  • 5-HT1F agonist: Causes inhibition of neuronal firing. E.g., Lasmiditan
  • Ergot alkaloids: Vasoconstrictor. E.g., Ergotamine
  • D2 Blockers: Metoclopramide
  • Opioids and NSAIDs

Prophylaxis of migraine

  • Propranolol (Beta-blocker, DOC for migraine prophylaxis).
  • Flunarizine (Calcium channel blocker)
  • Cyproheptadine: (Antihistamine that can help alleviate migraine symptoms).
  • Candesartan: (Angiotensin II receptor blocker).
  • Clonidine
  • Pizotifen (Serotonin antagonist that can help reduce migraine frequency).
  • Gabapentin, valproate, nortriptyline, and topiramate are medications that can help manage migraine symptoms by releasing the neurotransmitter GABA.
  • Topiramate
  • Methysergide (Manages migraine symptoms by blocking serotonin receptors).

questions.text: A 40-year-old man has been diagnosed with solid cancer of the bowel. He also experienced massive proteinuria a few months after the initial diagnosis of cancer. What do you think is the likely cause of the development of urinary findings?
questions.explanation:
Characteristic Features of Membranous Nephropathy

Feature

Description

Primary Cause

Autoantibodies against phospholipase A2 receptor (PLA2R) on podocytes (most common in idiopathic cases).

Secondary Causes

Autoimmune diseases (SLE), infections (Hepatitis B/C), drugs (NSAIDs, penicillamine), and malignancies (lung, breast, colon cancer).

Nephrotic Syndrome Features

Massive proteinuria (>3.5 g/day), hypoalbuminemia, oedema, hyperlipidemia, lipiduria.

Risk of Thrombosis

Renal vein thrombosis is a known complication.

Light Microscopy

Diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) without hypercellularity.

Electron Microscopy (EM)

Subepithelial immune deposits create a "spike and dome" appearance.

Immunofluorescence

Granular IgG and C3 deposits along the GBM.

PLA2R Antibodies

Specific for primary membranous nephropathy and helps differentiate from secondary causes.

Treatment

ACE inhibitors/ARBs (reduce proteinuria), steroids + immunosuppressants (cyclophosphamide, rituximab) for severe cases.

Prognosis

⅓ spontaneous remission, ⅓ persistent proteinuria, ⅓ progress to ESRD.

questions.text: A female patient presented with burning micturition. A diagnosis of cystitis was made. Which of the following drugs will be used for treatment?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - TMP-SMX is the first-line treatment for uncomplicated cystitis.

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole

MOA

Trimethoprim (TMP): Inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, blocking the conversion of dihydrofolate acid to tetrahydrofolic acid

Sulfamethoxazole (SMX): Inhibits dihydropteroate synthase, preventing the incorporation of para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA) into dihydropteroic acid, an essential precursor in folate synthesis.

Uses

  • Urinary tract infections (DOC for mild cases)
  • Respiratory tract infections
  • GIT Infections
  • Prevention and treatment of Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia in immunocompromised patients

Side effects
  • Nausea and Vomiting
  • Diarrhoea
  • Rash
  • Hypersensitivity reactions (including Stevens-Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis)
  • Blood dyscrasias (e.g., neutropenia, thrombocytopenia)

Note
  • Contraindicated in patients with folate deficiency
  • Use with caution in pregnant women, infants, and individuals with G6PD deficiency
  • Increased risk of hyperkalemia with potassium-sparing diuretics

A 26-year-old patient came with complaints of blurring of vision, photophobia, redness, pain in the left eye, and joint pain. Upon examination keratic precipitates and aqueous cells were observed. Which of the following major histocompatibility complex is be associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - HLA B27

Definition

Chronic inflammatory disease primarily affecting the axial skeleton (spine and sacroiliac joints), leading to pain, stiffness, and spinal fusion (bamboo spine).

Etiology

Unknown; genetic (HLA-B27) and environmental factors involved. HLA-B27 is positive in 90% of cases, but not all carriers develop AS.

Pathophysiology

Inflammation at entheses → Erosive changes → New bone formation → Syndesmophytes → Spinal fusion (ankylosis).

Clinical Features

Musculoskeletal Symptoms:

  • Chronic low back pain (worse after inactivity, better with activity)
  • Limited spinal mobility
  • Enthesitis (Achilles, plantar fascia)
  • Peripheral arthritis (hips, shoulders, knees)

Extra-articular Symptoms:

  • Ocular: Anterior uveitis (pain, redness, photophobia)
  • Cardiovascular: Aortic regurgitation, conduction issues
  • Pulmonary: Apical fibrosis
  • Gastrointestinal: Associated with IBD

Diagnosis

Based on clinical features, imaging studies, and HLA-B27 gene presence. Modified New York Criteria:

Clinical Criteria:

  • Low back pain > 3 months (improves with exercise, not with rest)
  • Limited lumbar spine motion (sagittal/frontal planes)
  • Reduced chest expansion (relative to age/sex)

Radiographic Criteria (X-ray): Bilateral sacroiliitis (grade 2-4) or unilateral sacroiliitis (grade 3-4)

Radiological Features:

  • Blurring/haziness of sacroiliac joint
  • Juxta-articular sclerosis
  • Vertical/bridging syndesmophytes
  • Squaring of vertebrae
  • Bamboo spine
  • Trolley track sign
  • Dagger sign
  • Shiny corner sign/Romanus lesion (inflammatory lesions at edges of vertebrae)

MRI: Early detection of inflammation

Clinical Tests:

For Sacroiliitis:

  • Gaenslen’s test
  • Patrick/FABER test
  • Figure of 4 test
  • Pump handle test

For Lumbar Spine:

Schober/ Modified Schober test

Laboratory Tests
  • HLA-B27 positive (90% of cases)
  • ESR, CRP: Elevated during active disease, but can be normal

Differential Diagnosis
  • Mechanical low back pain
  • Other spondyloarthropathies (e.g., psoriatic arthritis)
  • Degenerative disc disease
  • Fibromyalgia

Treatment

Non-Pharmacological:

  • Physical therapy (mobility/posture exercises)
  • Patient education on disease and exercise importance

Pharmacological:

  • NSAIDs (first-line for pain, stiffness)
  • TNF inhibitors (for NSAID-resistant cases)
  • IL-17 inhibitors (Secukinumab)
  • Sulfasalazine (for peripheral arthritis)
  • Corticosteroids (short-term flare control)

Surgical:

  • Hip replacement (for severe hip involvement)
  • Spinal surgery (for severe deformities/fractures)

Complications
  • Spinal fractures (minimal trauma)
  • Cardiac issues (aortic regurgitation, conduction defects)
  • Osteoporosis leading to fracture risk

Conditions mimicking Ankylosing Spondylitis with spinal fusion
  • Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis (DISH) (Forestier’s disease)
  • Ossification of Posterior Longitudinal Ligament (OPLL)
  • Spondylosis (Degenerative Disc Disease)
  • Psoriatic Arthritis
  • Enteropathic Arthritis (IBD-associated)
  • Reactive Arthritis
  • Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
  • Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA)

A 55-year-old woman is being counseled for surgery for her long-standing dacryocystitis. Which of the following is the surgery of choice?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR)

Aspect

Acute Dacryocystitis

Chronic Dacryocystitis

Aetiology
  • Acute exacerbation of chronic dacryocystitis
  • Spread from neighbouring infected structures (e.g., sinuses, bones, dental abscess)
  • Causative organisms: Streptococcus haemolyticus, Pneumococcus, Staphylococcus
  • Stasis and mild infection of long duration
  • Common in women aged 40-60
  • Causes: anatomical factors (narrow bony canal), nasal diseases, foreign bodies, infection.

Clinical Features/ Sequelae
  1. Stage of cellulitis: Painful swelling at the lacrimal sac, epiphora, fever, redness, and oedema.
  2. Lacrimal abscess: Pus-filled sac, fluctuant swelling, may rupture forming an abscess.
  3. Fistula formation: Untreated abscess leads to spontaneous discharge, forming a fistula.
  1. Stage of chronic catarrhal dacryocystitis: Watering eye, mild redness, NLD block
  2. Lacrimal mucocele: Swelling below inner canthus, mucoid fluid regurgitation.
  3. Chronic suppurative dacryocystitis: Purulent discharge (d/t infection), recurrent conjunctivitis.
  1. Chronic fibrotic sac: Thickened mucosa, persistent epiphora, irregular folds.

Image

 

Complications

Conjunctivitis, corneal ulcer, lid abscess, orbital cellulitis, facial cellulitis, rarely cavernous sinus thrombosis.

Conjunctivitis, ectropion of lower lid, risk of corneal ulcers.

Treatment
  • Cellulitis: Systemic antibiotics, anti-inflammatory drugs, hot fomentation.
  • Lacrimal abscess: Drainage with incision, antibiotics, possible DCT or DCR later.
  • External fistula: Fistulectomy with DCT or DCR after controlling infection.
  • Conservative: Probing and syringing (early stages).
  • Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR): Preferred surgery to re-establish lacrimal drainage.
  • Dacryocystectomy (DCT): Indicated if DCR is contraindicated or in cases of fibrosis, infection, or old age.

questions.text: The egg shown below belongs to? ​ ​ ​ ​
questions.explanation:
Morphology

Adult worm
  • The male worm is 30-45 mm long.
  • The female worm is 40-50 mm long (slightly larger).
  • Appearance:
    • Flesh-colored.
    • Whip-shaped: anterior (3/5) thin and thread-like; posterior (2/5) thick and fleshy (like a handle).
    • The end of the male worms is coiled ventrally.
    • The end of the female worm is straight, blunt, and rounded.
  • Body structure:
    • The anterior portion contains a capillary esophagus.
    • The posterior part contains the intestines and reproductive organs.
  • Lifespan: 5-10 years.

Eggs

Characteristics:

  • The eggs appear brown as they are bile-stained.
  • They are barrel-shaped.
  • They have a triple shell with a brown outer layer and a colorless mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum.

Infectivity:

  • Freshly passed eggs contain an unsegmented ovum and are not infective for humans.
  • The egg floats in a saturated salt solution.
  • The fertilized female lays about 5,000 eggs per day.

Epidemiology
  • Distribution:
    • Worldwide, with higher prevalence in tropical regions.
    • Common in tropical Africa, South America, and Southeast Asia.
    • Widespread in India.
  • Prevalence:
    • An estimated 800 million people are infected globally.
    • While whipworm infections are frequent, whipworm disease is relatively rare.

questions.text: An AIDS-positive patient came with a history of fever, vomiting, and meningismus. Which of the following tests help in the rapid diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis?

options.label: D
options.text: Urine lateral flow assay for cryptococcal antigen

questions.correct_answer: D. Urine lateral flow assay for cryptococcal antigen
questions.explanation:
Clinical features of cryptococcosis

Respiratory system

  • Cryptococcus typically enters the body via inhalation and can cause pulmonary infection / pneumonitis - primary site of infection
  • Patients may present with cough, pleuritic chest pain, and respiratory distress.
  • Imaging shows a solitary pulmonary nodule
  • Dissemination of pulmonary infection leads to involvement of involvement of other organs

Central Nervous System

Meningitis: Characterized by severe headaches, fever, altered mental status, sensory and memory loss, cranial nerve paresis and loss of vision

It is the most serious type of cryptococcal infection

Skin

Cutaneous Cryptococcosis: Causes skin lesions, particularly in immunocompromised patients.

Associated with C.neoformans var neoformans (serotype D)

Other Organs

Liver, spleen, and bones maybe involved in disseminated infections

Management of cryptococcosis

Microscopy

  • India ink- Demonstrates the capsule, which appears as clear space surrounding the round budding yeast cells
  • Mucicarmine stain: It stains the carminophilic cell wall of C. neoformans

Culture
  • Sabouraud Dextrose Agar, forming smooth, mucoid, cream-coloured colonies.
  • Niger seed agar and bird seed agar: Demonstrates melanin production (brown colored colonies) due to phenol oxidase/laccase enzyme.
  • The ability to grow at 37°C and hydrolyse urea differentiates C. neoformans from non-pathogenic cryptococci

Antigen detection tests

Demonstration of the capsular antigen by Precipitation and Latex agglutination test

Urine Lateral Flow Assay for Cryptococcal Antigen- Best rapid diagnostic test.

Treatment

  • Initial Treatment with liposomal Amphotericin B and Flucytosine
  • Maintenance Therapy with Fluconazole for 6-12 months, depending on immune status.
  • Monitoring: Regularly check CSF for fungal clearance, renal function, and electrolytes.
  • Management of Underlying Conditions: Optimize ART to reduce recurrence risk.

questions.text: Molluscum contagiosum is caused by
questions.explanation:
Poxviruses

Poxviruses are the largest viruses that infect vertebrates.

Morphology

  • Poxviruses measure approximately 400 nm in length and 230 nm in diameter, making them visible under a light microscope.
  • Poxviruses are typically brick-shaped or ellipsoid.
  • They possess an envelope consisting of two lipoprotein membranes (outer and inner), and the outer membrane features ridges.
  • The envelope encases a core, along with two structures of unknown function known as lateral bodies.
  • The core or nucleocapsid is biconcave and shaped like a dumbbell.
  • Poxviruses contain a single linear double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) genome.
  • They are unique among DNA viruses for replicating in the cytoplasm.

Human-Important poxviruses
  • Variola is the causative agent of smallpox, the first disease to be eradicated globally.
  • Vaccinia: Used as a vaccine for smallpox.
  • Molluscum contagiosum Virus: Causes warty lesions known as molluscum contagiosum.

Genera classification

  • Orthopoxvirus: Smallpox, monkeypox, vaccinia.
  • Molluscipoxvirus: Molluscum contagiosum.
  • Parapoxvirus: Milker’s nodules, bovine papular stomatitis viruses, etc.
  • Capripoxvirus: Sheeppox, goatpox, lumpy skin disease, etc.
  • Avipoxvirus: Fowlpox, pigeon pox, etc.
  • Leporipoxvirus: Myxoma, hare fibroma, etc.
  • Suipoxvirus: Swinepox virus.
  • Yatapoxvirus: Tanapox, Yabapox viruses.

Molluscum contagiosum

Molluscum contagiosum virus is an obligate human poxvirus known for producing characteristic skin lesions.

Clinical manifestations

Lesions:

  • Dome-shaped, pink, pearly wart-like lesions (2–5 mm in size) with a dimple at the center.
  • Lesions can appear singly or in clusters, located anywhere on the body except on the palms and soles.
  • Lesions are umbilicated.
  • Genital lesions are commonly observed in adults.
  • Lesions typically resolve on their own within 3–4 months.

Transmission

  • Primarily affects children, transmitted through direct and indirect contact (e.g., barbers, shared towels, swimming pools).
  • Rare instances of sexual transmission have been reported in young adults.

Laboratory diagnosis

Molluscum bodies:

  • Characteristic intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions were observed in skin scrapings stained with histopathological stains.

Confirmation methods:

  • Electron microscopy
  • PCR

Cultivation:

  • The virus cannot be propagated in tissue culture, embryonated eggs, or animals.

Treatment
  • Surgical removal of the lesions by ablation (by cryotherapy or laser therapy) is the mainstay of treatment.
  • Cidofovir has been shown to have some efficacy.

questions.text: Blount Disease results from the involvement of
questions.explanation:
Infantile Blount disease

Adolescent Blount disease
  • Diagnosed in children between age 1-3 years.
  • Bilateral condition.
  • Characterised by varus deformity of tibia with identification of lateral thrust.
  • Emerges in children in their late childhood or early adolescent.
  • Unilateral or bilateral conditions.
  • Characterised by pain in the medial aspect of the knee.

Angles

Description

Metaphyseal-Diaphyseal angle(MDA)
  • The intersection occurs between a line drawn from the most distal point on the medial and lateral beaks of the tibial metaphysis to a line perpendicular to the long axis of the tibial diaphysis.
  • An angle >16° is associated with a 95% risk of deformity progression.
  • An angle <10° is likely physiological, with a 95% chance of spontaneous resolution.
  • An angle between 11° and 16° necessitates close observation for the potential tibia vara progression.

Tibiofemoral angle
  • Measures the severity of varus deformity.

Medial Metaphyseal Beak angle(MMBA)
  • Diagnostic screening tool for individual risk of blount disease.

questions.text: Which joints are affected in a condition where the distal interphalangeal (DIP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints are involved, while the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and wrist are spared?
A 35 year old man presented with a gradual progressive swelling, and was diagnosed with Adamantinoma. Which of the following bones is typically affected by this tumor?
questions.explanation:
Adamantinoma

About
  • Rare, low-grade malignant bone tumors of uncertain histogenesis
  • Commonly affects the anterior metaphysis and diaphysis tibia, close to the skin surface.
  • Immunohistochemical studies suggest epithelial origin.
  • Commonly affects individuals aged 20-40 years.

Histopathology
  • Macroscopic: Well-defined, lobulated cortical tumors with yellowish-gray appearance and possible cystic spaces.
  • Microscopic: Biphasic composition (epithelial and osteofibrous components) with basaloid, tubular, spindle-cell, squamous, and osteofibrous dysplasia-like patterns.
  • Immunohistochemistry:
    • Epithelial cells: Positive for keratin, EMA, vimentin, p63, podoplanin.
    • Fibrous component: Positive for vimentin.
    • Expression of EGF, EGFR (epithelial), FGF2, FGFR1 (both components).

Clinical Features
  • Prolonged clinical course with slow-growing swelling, possible pain, bone deformities, or pathological fractures (~23%).
  • Rarely involves neurological deficits when the spine is affected.
  • Metastases commonly involve lungs, lymph nodes, or spine.

Evaluation
  • X-ray: Well-circumscribed, multilobulated, osteolytic cortical tumor with a "soap-bubble" appearance.
  • CT Scan: Assesses soft tissue extension and cortical involvement.
  • MRI: Locoregional staging; visualizes tumor margins, cortical involvement, and soft tissue extension.

Treatment
  • Wide Resection: En bloc removal with wide margins preferred.
  • Metastasectomy: First-line for pulmonary recurrences.

questions.text: Albers Schonberg disease is
questions.explanation:
Osteopetrosis

Osteopetrosis, also known as Albers-Schönberg disease, is a rare condition characterized by abnormally dense bones due to defective osteoclast function, which impairs bone resorption.

As a result, bones become thickened but brittle, leading to structural abnormalities and complications. (Option A ruled out)

Types

Infantile Malignant Osteopetrosis

Features

Adult Benign Osteopetrosis

Autosomal recessive

Inheritance

Autosomal dominant

(Option B ruled out)

Early onset with severe symptoms, including growth retardation, genu valgum, abnormal skull development, cranial nerve entrapment, pancytopenia, and hepatosplenomegaly.

(Option C)

Presentation

 

Often asymptomatic and discovered incidentally in adulthood. When symptomatic, it may present with non-specific bone pain, compressive neuropathies, and recurrent fractures.

(Option D ruled out)

Increased risk of hydrocephalus, hearing loss, and osteitis of the mandible.

Complications

Delayed union

Symptom management with vitamin D, γ-interferon, erythropoietin, and corticosteroids.

Treatment

Generally not required unless symptoms are present. Symptomatic management includes pain relief and fracture care.

Findings in osteopetrosis

Rugger Jersey Spine (Also seen in renal osteodystrophy)

Sandwich Vertebra

Endplates of the vertebra become densely sclerotic resembling a sandwich.

Densely Sclerotic bones

A chronic asthmatic patient who is on inhaled steroids presents with a history of burning sensation on eating hot or spicy food, and the following findings are seen. What is the most possible diagnosis?

Oral candidiasis

Oral candidiasis, commonly known as thrush, is an infection caused by an overgrowth of Candida albicans, a type of yeast.

Presentation

Presence of white patches that can be scraped off leaving behind a red inflamed base

Risk factors

  • Diabetes: Poorly controlled diabetes creates a favorable environment for Candida growth due to elevated blood sugar levels.
  • Neutropenia
  • Immunosuppression: HIV/AIDS, cancer, or immunosuppressive medications increases susceptibility.
  • Use of inhaled corticosteroids
  • Antibiotic Use: Broad-spectrum antibiotics can disrupt normal oral flora, allowing Candida to overgrow.
  • Poor Oral Hygiene: Lead to an increase in fungal colonization.
  • Dry Mouth: Conditions that lead to reduced saliva production can promote candidiasis.

Treatment
  • Antifungal medications, such as nystatin or fluconazole, along with addressing any underlying risk factors.
  • C. krusei- Resistant to azoles

questions.text: A 79 yrs old lady had a fall in the bathroom, the following X-rays were taken in order to make a diagnosis. Which of the following is treatment of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Etiology

Low-Energy Trauma

Common in elderly with osteoporosis; simple fall from standing height can cause a fracture.

Osteoporosis

Age-related bone loss; post-menopausal women at higher risk; fractures occur with minimal trauma.

Pathological Fractures

Caused by conditions like metastatic bone disease, multiple myeloma, or Paget’s disease; minimal force needed for fracture.

Stress Fractures

Seen in athletes or military personnel due to repetitive stress.

Clinical Presentation

Pain

Groin pain radiating to medial thigh or knee; sharp pain worsened by movement.

Inability to Bear Weight

Unable to stand or walk due to pain, less severe in stress fractures.

Attitude of affected limb

Shortened and externally rotated limb in displaced fractures; limited internal rotation and flexion.

Bruising and Swelling

Minimal swelling due to deep femoral neck location; sometimes bruising around hip or groin.

Diagnosis

Imaging

X-ray (AP and lateral views) is the primary modality; fractures are classified using the Garden classification.

 

Treatment Options
  • Non-displaced: Internal fixation (e.g., cannulated screws)
  • Displaced: Surgical fixation (hemiarthroplasty, total hip replacement)

Complications

High risk of nonunion and avascular necrosis

 

Garden’s classification

Treatment in adults

Treatment in children

Garden’s type 1

(incomplete, impacted, or abducted fracture)
  • Conservative methods
  • Immobilization in a Thomas splint with traction
  • Internal fixation with screws (if displacement is feared)
  • Hip spica (Option B ruled out)
  • Traction is applied through a pin (Moore’s pin) or wire in older adolescents

Garden’s type 2

(complete but undisplaced)

Internal fixation with cannulated screws, dynamic hip screws, proximal femoral locking plates, and cephalomedullary nails.

Garden’s type 3

(complete & partially displaced)

  • Hemiarthroplasty (done in inactive elderly of >60years of age with comorbidities)
  • Total hip arthroplasty (done in active older patients)
  • Internal fixation (done in young adults)

Internal fixation (using Knowle’s screw)

Garden’s type 4

(complete & fully displaced)

Explanation

Bagging

(Option B)
  • Bagging refers to a method of inhaling substances by placing them inside a bag and then inhaling or breathing in the vapors.

Huffing

(Option D)
  • Huffing involves the deliberate inhalation of volatile substances or inhalants directly from their container or source.
  • This method is associated with the misuse of chemicals, solvents, or other volatile substances for recreational purposes.

questions.text: While collecting a blood sample for investigations, you accidentally dropped a 5 ml tube of blood and spilled blood. Which among the following is the best solution to clean it?
questions.explanation:
Examples
  • Tincture Iodine (2% Iodine): bactericidal + sporicidal
  • Povidone Iodine (Betadine): has residual action
  • Sodium hypochlorite (5.25%): Both bactericidal + virucidal

Mechanism of action
  • Oxidisation

Uses

  • Skin antiseptic, wound dressing (Betadine preferred)
  • Town water supply, Swimming pools (Chlorine)
  • Sodium hypochlorite: Blood spills (1:10/1:100 dilution of 5.25% solution used)

questions.text: A man was found to be lying dead on the ground. His friend saw a snake passing in the area and took a picture of it and showed it to the doctor (image below). What is the most probable cause of death of this man?

A 34-year-old HIV-positive male presented with low-grade fever, cough, night sweats, and weight loss for the past 3 weeks. In view of TB investigations, the Mantoux test was negative; chest X-ray showed non-specific findings, and an adequate amount of sputum could not be collected for slide examination. Which of the following is used to diagnose latent TB infection in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Investigations

Purpose

Advantages

Limitations

Sputum smear

  • Initial screening for pulmonary TB.
  • Samples are stained using the Ziehl-Neelsen method or Auramine-O stain to visualize acid-fast bacilli (AFB) under a microscope.
  • Quick and inexpensive. Can provide results within a few hours.
  • Low sensitivity, especially in cases of extrapulmonary TB or in patients with HIV.
  • Cannot differentiate between Mycobacterium tuberculosis and non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM).

Culture Methods
  • Confirm the diagnosis of TB and assess drug susceptibility.
  • Solid Media: Sputum is inoculated onto solid culture media like Löwenstein-Jensen or Middlebrook agar.
  • Liquid Media: Automated systems like BACTEC or MGIT are used to detect growth faster.
  • The gold standard for TB diagnosis.
  • Allows for drug susceptibility testing.
  • Time-consuming; results can take weeks.
  • Requires specialized laboratory facilities.

Xpert MTB/RIF
  • Detects Mycobacterium tuberculosis and rifampicin resistance.
  • Method:
  • A cartridge-based system that performs nucleic acid amplification (NAAT).
  • Sputum or other specimens are processed directly in the cartridge.
  • Rapid results (within 2 hours).
  • High sensitivity and specificity.
  • Simultaneously detects rifampicin resistance.
  • More expensive than smear microscopy.
  • Does not provide full drug susceptibility testing.

LAMP (Loop-Mediated Isothermal Amplification)
  • Detects DNA of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • Method:
  • Amplifies DNA at a constant temperature without the need for thermal cycling.
  • Sputum or other specimens are used.
  • Rapid results (within 1-2 hours).
  • High specificity and sensitivity.
  • Can be performed at the point of care.
  • Used for patients with HIV with CD4+ counts of less than 100 cells/μL irrespective of signs and symptoms of TB.
  • Less widely available than PCR-based tests.
  • Cannot detect drug resistance directly.

TrueNat
  • Point-of-care test for TB detection.
  • Method:
  • Uses a micro-PCR technology to amplify DNA.
  • Results are available within 60 minutes.
  • Portable and easy to use in peripheral health facilities.
  • Provides results quickly, facilitating immediate treatment decisions.
  

Line Probe Assay (LPA)
  • Detects TB and drug resistance (rifampicin and isoniazid).
  • Method:
    • Sputum samples are processed, and DNA is extracted.
    • Amplified DNA is hybridized to specific probes on a membrane strip.
  • Rapid results (within 1-2 days).
  • Can detect multiple mutations associated with drug resistance.
  • Requires a laboratory setup and trained personnel.
  • Not suitable for all strains of TB.

RFLP
  • IS6110 restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) analysis is widely used for molecular epidemiological studies of tuberculosis.
  • Restriction enzymes Nru I, EcoN I, Pst I, and Pvu II were used to analyze IS6110 fingerprints in Mycobacterium tuberculosis strains H37Rv (virulent) and H37Ra (avirulent).

questions.text: The World Health Organization (WHO) has defined blindness as a condition where the level of visual acuity is below
questions.explanation:
WHO Classification of Visual Impairment
  • The World Health Organization (WHO) defines blindness as "visual acuity of less than 3/60 (Snellen) or its equivalent".
  • The International Classification of Disease 11 (2018) classifies vision impairment into distance and near-presenting vision impairment

Classification

Visual Acuity

Mild Distance Vision Impairment

Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/12

Moderate Distance Vision Impairment

Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/18 (Option D ruled out)

Severe Distance Vision Impairment

Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/60 (Option A ruled out)

Blindness

Presenting visual acuity worse than 3/60 (Option B)

Near Vision Impairment

Presenting near vision acuity worse than N6 or M0.8 at 40 cm with existing correction (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 45-year-old healthy man with a history of small streaks of blood in his stools is being sent for a colonoscopy to screen for colon cancer. This type of prevention is-
questions.explanation:
Levels of prevention

Definition

Primordial (Option A ruled out)
  • Prevention of establishment of risk factors.
  • It aims to discourage people from adopting harmful habits.

Primary (Option C ruled out)

 
  • Prevention of onset of disease in a high-risk group/individual.
  • It aims to protect the health of those who are at risk.
  • Reduces the incidence of the disease.

Secondary (Option B)
  • Disease progression can be prevented at an early stage (Disease is reversible).
  • It aims to reduce the prevalence of the disease by early identification and prompt treatment of diseases, and it also prevents complications.

Tertiary (Option D ruled out)
  • Prevention or limitation of impairment and disability in a diseased patient who has developed complications due to the disease and the disease has become irreversible.
  • It aims to minimise a patient's suffering and maximise potential years of useful life.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with complaints of fever and sore throat. On examination, he has extensive cervical swelling and a well-demarcated white-gray exudative substance adherent to his oropharynx and attempts to remove this membrane result in bleeding. The parents report that all his childhood vaccines were skipped due to religious beliefs. A throat swab under Albert's staining is as below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Diphtheria

Clinical Features

Complications
  • Sore throat
  • Difficulty swallowing (dysphagia)
  • Low-grade fever
  • Grey Pseudomembrane formation in the throat that bleeds on removal
  • Non-healing ulcers covered by grey membrane on the skin
  • Myocarditis
  • Neurological complications (e.g., paralysis, neuropathy)
  • Renal failure
  • Airway obstruction

Culture Media

Colony appearance

Evaluation

Loeffler’s serum slope
  • Small
  • Circular opaque disks
  • Glistening,
  • White with a yellow tinge
  • Advantage: Growth can be detected as early as 6–8 hours.
  • The best medium for metachromatic granule production
  • Disadvantage: Supports the growth of other throat commensals also

Potassium tellurite agar

(McLeod’s and Hoyle’s-modified PTA)
  • Grey or black colour
  • Advantage: Throat commensals are inhibited
  • Disadvantage: Colonies appear only after 48 hours of incubation

Sheep blood agar
  • Small
  • Circular
  • White
  • Sometimes hemolytic(mitis biotype)
  • Differentiate colonies from streptococcal or staphylococcal pharyngitis, which may simulate diphtheria.
  • The serum slope may show growth in 4-8 hours but, if negative, will have to be incubated for 24 hours

Type

Components

Function

Albert Solution 1
  • Malachite Green for organism staining
  • Toluidine Blue for metachromatic staining
  • Enhances contrast and specificity in staining.

Albert Solution 2
  • Iodine
  • Specifically targets volutin or Babes-Ernst granules.

questions.text: An unknown disease of suspected infectious origin has come up in your town. As a microbiologist, you collect the relevant samples and detect the etiological cause. Which of the following types of PCR would you do?

A study was done to assess nutritional status among young children in rural and urban areas. 40 children in rural and 30 children in urban areas were malnourished. Which of the following tests of significance is the most appropriate in this case?
questions.explanation:
Parametric Test

Description

Paired Student's t-test (Option B ruled out)

Used to compare means (± SD) in paired data from the same group of individuals before and after an intervention.

Unpaired Student's t-test

Used to compare means (± SD) in two different groups of individuals. The Z-test is a variant of the unpaired Student's t-test used when the sample size is > 30.

ANOVA (Option D ruled out)

Used to compare means (± SD) in more than two different groups of individuals.

Pearson correlation coefficient

Measures the linear association between two variables and can range from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 30-year-old woman who previously had dilatation and curettage, and now presents with amenorrhea, a negative urine pregnancy test, and a honeycomb appearance in the uterine cavity on HSG?
What is the quickest method for laboratory diagnosis of pulmonary tuberculosis?
questions.explanation:
Diagnostic Modality

Description

Usage

Sputum Smear Microscopy (Option B ruled out)

Microscopic examination of sputum samples to detect acid-fast bacilli (AFB).

Used for initial screening and diagnosis, especially in resource-limited settings.

Chest X-ray

Imaging done to identify abnormalities suggestive of TB.

Used to support diagnosis when clinical suspicion is high; not definitive for TB diagnosis.

TruNAAT/CBNAAT (Option A)

Molecular tests that detect Mycobacterial DNA and rifampicin resistance.

Recommended for initial diagnosis due to high sensitivity and specificity; rapid results.

Line Probe Assay (LPA)

Molecular test to detect specific genetic mutations associated with drug resistance (e.g., rifampicin, isoniazid).

Used for detecting drug resistance in confirmed TB cases, not for initial diagnosis.

Tuberculin Skin Test (TST)

A skin test to measure immune response to injected tuberculin protein.

Primarily used for screening latent TB infection; not specific for active TB diagnosis.

Interferon-Gamma Release Assays (IGRAs)

Blood cytokine analysis test that measures immune response to TB antigens.

Used for detecting latent TB infection

Sputum Culture (Option C ruled out)

 

Growing Mycobacteria from sputum samples to confirm TB and test for drug susceptibility.

Gold standard for TB diagnosis; takes several weeks to obtain results.

Drug Susceptibility Testing (DST)

Testing TB bacteria from patient samples to determine resistance to TB drugs.

Used to guide treatment by identifying drug-resistant strains in confirmed TB cases.

questions.text: Please determine the study design based on the following information:
What is the duration after which the polymorphic rash of Varicella is no longer contagious?
questions.correct_answer: D. After crust formation over lesions
questions.explanation:
Agent

 
  • Varicella-zoster virus (HHV 3- Human Herpes Virus 3)
  • Double-stranded DNA virus.

Source of infection
 

 
  • Scabs are not infectious, but the vesicular fluid is infectious. (Option D)
  • Airborne- spreads via both droplet infection and droplet nuclei

Period of communicability

 
  • 1-2 days before and 4-5 days after the onset of the rash (crust formation)
  • Secondary attack rate- 85%

Host factors

 
  • Age: <10 years
  • Very common in school-going children
  • One attack gives lifelong immunity
  • Reactivation can occur as Varicella zoster infection in later age

Environmental factors
  • More common in winter and early spring
  • The virus can survive outside the body for 24-48 hours.
  • Disinfectants easily kill the virus.

Incubation period
  • More common in winter and early spring
  • The virus can survive outside the body for 24-48 hours.
  • Disinfectants easily kill the virus.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the difference in the incidence of asthma in children who are exposed to second-hand smoke and those who are not. If he wishes to express the additional incidence of asthma in the exposed children as a percentage, which of the following should he use?
questions.explanation:
Measure

Definition

Calculation

Attributable Risk

Proportion of disease incidence attributable to a specific exposure or risk factor

Risk in exposed group - Risk in unexposed group

Relative Risk

Risk of a particular outcome in the exposed group compared to the unexposed group

Risk in exposed group/Risk in unexposed group

Population Attributable Risk

Proportion of disease cases in a population attributable to a specific exposure or risk factor

(Prevalence of exposure) x (Relative risk-1)/(1+ (Prevalence of exposure) x (Relative risk - 1))

Odds Ratio

Strength of association between exposure and outcome in case-control or retrospective studies

(Exposure odds in cases/Non-exposure odds in cases) / (Exposure odds in controls/Non- exposure odds in controls)

questions.text: Komal, a 2-year-old girl is brought to the clinic with a high fever, cough, red eyes, and rash. Parents say that the rash started on the forehead and behind the ears, then subsequently spread to the neck and body. On examination, a confluent maculopapular rash is noted as shown below. Which of the following is false regarding this child's condition?

options.label: A
options.text: The period of infectivity is 3 days before and 5 days after the appearance of rash

options.label: B
options.text: The most common cause of death is subacute sclerosing panencephalitis

options.label: C
options.text: Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells are associated with the disease

questions.correct_answer: B. The most common cause of death is subacute sclerosing panencephalitis
questions.explanation:
Measles

Causative agent
  • ssRNA paramyxovirus

Incubation period
  • 10 days from exposure to onset of fever and 14 days to the appearance of rash

Source of infection
  • Person with measles
  • Infective material

Period of communicability
  • Roughly 4 days before and 4 days after the appearance of rash (Option A ruled out)

Clinical features

Prodromal stage:

  • Fever
  • Cough
  • Coryza with sneezing
  • Conjunctivitis with lacrimation
  • Koplik’s spots- grayish-white spots on the buccal mucosa (Pathognomonic feature) (Option D ruled out)

 

Eruptive stage:

  • Dusky red macular/maculopapular rash, which starts behind the ears and progresses to the face, neck and then to trunks and limbs.
  • In the absence of complications, the lesions and fever disappear after 3-4 days.

 

Post measles stage:

  • After the eruptive stage, it leads to weight loss, weakness, fatigue, diarrhea.

Isolation period
  • 7 days from the onset of rash

Difference between measles and rubella rash
  • Both rashes are maculopapular
  • The rash in measles is more confluent and botchy, whereas the rash in rubella is discrete or non-confluent.

Diagnosis
  • Clinically diagnosed based on rash and koplik’s spots
  • Gold standard: PCR

Treatment
  • No specific treatment
  • Symptomatic management only

Complications of Measles

Otitis Media

M/c complication in young children. Covered under IMNCI programme.

Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis (SSPE)

A rare, fatal brain disease that occurs years after measles infection, causing neurological damage and mortality. (Option B)

Pneumonia

Most common fatal complication & cause of death.

Persistent Diarrhea

Long-lasting diarrhea, potentially leading to protein-losing enteropathy.

Prevalent in developing countries, impacting infants significantly.

Keratomalacia

Measles causes acute vitamin A deficiency in children.

Giant Cell Pneumonia, Measles Inclusion-body Encephalitis

Primarily affects immunocompromised individuals.

Other complications: Laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup), Encephalitis, Spontaneous abortion, Premature delivery

questions.text: What is the obstetric grip being depicted in the image?
questions.explanation:
Maneuver

Position

Technique

Purpose

Fundal Grip

(First Leopold)

Facing the patient’s face

Palpate the fundal area with both hands

To determine which fetal pole is in the fundus:

  • Broad, soft, irregular mass: Breech
  • Smooth, hard, globular mass: Head
  • Transverse lie: Neither pole palpable

Lateral or Umbilical Grip

(Second Leopold)

Facing the patient’s face

Place hands flat on either side of the umbilicus, palpate one side at a time

To identify the position of the fetal back, limbs, and anterior shoulder:

  • Back: Smooth, curved, resistant
  • Limb side: Comparatively empty with small, knob-like parts
  • Anterior shoulder: Prominent in the lower part of the uterus above the head

Pawlik’s Grip

(Third Leopold)

Facing the patient’s face

Place thumb and four fingers over the lower pole of the uterus, ulnar border on the upper symphysis pubis

To grasp the presenting part if not engaged and test its mobility:

Transverse lie: Pawlik’s grip is empty

Pelvic Grip

(Fourth Leopold)

Facing the patient’s feet

Place four fingers of both hands on either side of the midline in the lower pole of the uterus, pressing downward and backward
  • To identify the part in the lower pole, its attitude, and engagement:

Head Characteristics:

  1. Precise presenting area
  2. Attitude (position of sinciput and occiput)
  3. Engagement (noted by the presence/absence of sinciput and occiput, convergence/divergence of finger tips)

questions.text: In the anteroposterior diameters of the pelvic inlet, the true conjugate is?

options.label: A
options.text: The distance from the midpoint of the sacral promontory to the uppermost margin of the symphysis pubis

options.label: B
options.text: The shortest distance between the sacral promontory and the symphysis pubis

options.label: C
options.text: The distance from the lowest margin of the symphysis to the sacral promontory

options.label: D
options.text: The distance from the posterior margin of the sacral promontory to the symphysis pubis

questions.correct_answer: A. The distance from the midpoint of the sacral promontory to the uppermost margin of the symphysis pubis
questions.explanation:
True Conjugate (Conjugata Vera)

The shortest distance between the sacral promontory and the superior margin of the pubic symphysis.

Determines pelvic inlet adequacy for vaginal delivery; <9.5 cm suggests possible cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD).

Diagonal Conjugate

(Option C)

The distance between the sacral promontory and the lower margin of the pubic symphysis, measured via the vaginal exam.

Estimates true conjugate; <12 cm may indicate a narrow pelvic inlet.

Obstetric Conjugate

(Option B)

The shortest distance between the sacral promontory and the posterior surface of the pubic symphysis.

Assesses pelvic cavity adequacy for fetal head passage; inadequate may lead to obstructed labor.

A primigravida presents with labor pain, and on per vaginal examination, her cervix is 7 cm dilated and fully effaced. What stage of labor is she in?
questions.explanation:
Stage

Definition

Features

Contractions

First Stage

Onset of labor to full cervical dilatation (10 cm).

  • Latent Phase: Early cervical changes with slower progress.
  • Active Phase: Faster cervical dilatation (≥5 cm) with regular contractions.
  • Cervical dilatation and effacement occur.
  • Intermittent painful uterine contractions.
  • "Show" (blood-stained mucus) is common.
  • Active labor starts at cervical dilatation ≥5 cm with regular contractions.

Latent Phase: Irregular and mild.

Active Phase: Regular; 3–5 min apart, lasting ~45 seconds.

Second Stage

From complete cervical dilatation (10 cm) to fetal delivery.
  • Begins after complete cervical dilation.
  • Ends with the delivery of the baby.

Strong and frequent; 2–3 minutes apart.

Third Stage

From fetal delivery to placental expulsion.
  • Placental separation and expulsion occur.
  • Average duration: 5–15 minutes.

Mild uterine contractions to aid placental expulsion.

Fourth Stage

Observation for at least 1 hour after placental expulsion.
  • Monitoring for postpartum hemorrhage and uterine contraction.

Uterine contractions continue, aiding hemostasis.

questions.text: A child presents with continuing seizures for the past 30 minutes. The relatives say that there had been no seizure-free intervals in the past 30 minutes. After stabilizing the vitals, what is the first drug that should be administered?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A- Diazepam

Management of Status Epilepticus:

Status epilepticus is a medical emergency characterized by continuous seizure activity or recurrent seizures without recovery of consciousness between episodes. The definition has evolved to recognize the importance of early intervention:

  • Traditional definition: seizures lasting >30 minutes

  • Current definition: continuous seizures lasting ≥5 minutes, or two or more seizures without full recovery between them

Early intervention is critical as neuronal damage can begin to occur after 5-30 minutes of continuous seizure activity.

Initial Assessment and Stabilization (0-5 minutes)

  1. Stabilize airway, breathing, and circulation

    • Position patient appropriately to maintain open airway

    • Assess oxygenation and provide oxygen via nasal cannula/mask

    • Monitor vital signs continuously

    • Consider intubation if respiratory assistance is needed

  2. Initial assessment

    • Perform quick neurological exam if possible

    • Check blood glucose levels (treat if <60 mg/dl)

    • Secure IV access

  3. Laboratory tests to obtain

    • Electrolytes, hematology, toxicology screen

    • Anticonvulsant drug levels (if on medication)

First-Line Treatment (5-20 minutes)

 

A benzodiazepine is the initial therapy of choice:

  • Intravenous lorazepam: 0.1 mg/kg up to maximum of 4 mg, may repeat in 5-10 min

  • Intravenous midazolam: 0.2 mg/kg up to 10 mg total dose, may repeat in 5-10 min

  • Intramuscular midazolam: 0.2 mg/kg (if IV access not available)

  • Rectal diazepam: 0.5 mg/kg (if IV access not available)

  • Buccal midazolam: 0.5 mg/kg (if IV access not available)

Second-Line Treatment (20-40 minutes)

 

If seizures continue after benzodiazepine administration, proceed to one of these options:

  • Intravenous fosphenytoin: 20 mg PE/kg loading dose (maximum 1500 mg/dose)

  • Intravenous valproate: 40 mg/kg loading dose (maximum 3000 mg/dose)

  • Intravenous levetiracetam: 30-60 mg/kg loading dose (maximum 4500 mg/dose)

  • Intravenous phenobarbital: 15-20 mg/kg loading dose (if not given initially)

Third-Line Treatment (40-60 minutes)

 

If seizures still continue (refractory status epilepticus):

  • Consider repeating second-line therapy

  • Consider anesthetic doses of:

    • Thiopental

    • Midazolam

    • Pentobarbital

    • Propofol (with caution in children due to propofol infusion syndrome risk)

Continuous EEG monitoring is recommended at this stage.

questions.text: Which of the following congenital heart disease presents with split-second heart sounds? Atrial Septal Defect (ASD) Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA) Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A- Only 1,2,3 is correct

Examination findings in TOF

Cardiac Auscultation
  • Heart Sounds: Typically normal first heart sound with a single second heart sound (pulmonic component usually inaudible)
  • Murmur: Harsh systolic ejection murmur, crescendo-decrescendo in quality
    • Best heard at the left mid to upper sternal border
    • Radiates posteriorly
    • The severity of the murmur correlates with the degree of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction
    • May occasionally have a regurgitant quality
  • Early systolic click: Sometimes heard along the left sternal border (attributed to flow through a dilated ascending aorta)
  • Continuous murmur: Present over the back and axillary regions in patients with pulmonary atresia and aortopulmonary collaterals

Palpation
  • Prominent ventricular impulse
  • Systolic thrill may be palpable along the left sternal border

 

Wide Splitting
  • Occurs in conditions like right bundle branch block (RBBB) due to delayed pulmonic valve closure.
  • Seen in severe mitral regurgitation (MR) due to premature closure of the aortic valve- Wide and variable split is seen.
  • Seen in VSD

Narrow Splitting or Singular S2
  • Narrow Splitting- E.g. Aortic stenosis or Patent Ductus Arteriosus

Wide Fixed Splitting
  • The A2-P2 interval is wide and does not change during the respiratory cycle. E.g.- ASD, TAPVC, RVF

Reversed or Paradoxical Splitting- P2 before A2
  • Seen in conditions such as left bundle branch block (LBBB).
  • Right ventricular pacing.
  • Severe aortic stenosis (AS).
  • Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM),
  • Acute myocardial ischemia.

Loud P2
  • Considered loud when its intensity exceeds A2 at the base or can be palpated in the proximal main pulmonary artery area. E.g.- Pulmonary arterial hypertension.

Decreased Intensity
  • A2 intensity decreases with aortic stenosis (AS) and P2 intensity decreases with pulmonic stenosis (PS), potentially resulting in a single S2.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of jaundice in this newborn presenting with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, intrahepatic cholestasis, high alkaline phosphatase, and the presence of eosinophilic, PAS-positive cytoplasmic granules in liver biopsy specimens, suggestive of Alpha 1 AT deficiency?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B- Neonatal h

Neonatal Hepatitis

Definition
  • Inflammation of the liver in newborn infants
  • Characterized by liver dysfunction
  • Presents with jaundice, hepatomegaly, and abnormal liver function tests

Infectious Causes

1. Hepatitis viruses (A, B, C, D, E)

  • Transmitted from mother to baby during pregnancy/childbirth

2. Other viruses:

  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV)
  • Herpes simplex virus (HSV)
  • Rubella virus

Metabolic Causes

1. Bilirubin metabolism disorders:

  • Gilbert syndrome
  • Crigler-Najjar syndrome

2. Carbohydrate metabolism defects:

  • Galactosemia

3. Amino acid metabolism disorders:

  • Tyrosinemia

Immune-mediated Causes
  • Autoimmune hepatitis
  • Neonatal lupus
  • Immune system attacks and damages the liver

Drug-induced Causes

Maternal medications that can cause liver damage:

  • Anticonvulsants
  • Antibiotics
  • NSAIDs

Transfer occurs during pregnancy or breastfeeding

Diagnosis Methods

1. Clinical presentation

2. Physical examination

3. Blood tests:

  • Liver function tests
  • Viral serology

4. Imaging studies:

  • Ultrasound
  • MRI

5. Liver biopsy (in some cases)

Treatment Approaches

1. Viral hepatitis:

  • Supportive care
  • Antiviral medications (specific cases)

2. Metabolic disorders:

  • Dietary modifications
  • Enzyme replacement therapy
  • Specific treatments for metabolic defects

3. Immune-mediated hepatitis:

  • Immunosuppressive medications

4. Drug-induced hepatitis:

  • Discontinuation of offending medication

questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C- Oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs, and send home

Pneumonia Classification: WHO IMNCI Guidelines

Signs

Classify as

Treatment

Presence of any general danger sign

Severe pneumonia or very severe disease

Give 1 dose of inj ampicillin & gentamycin & refer urgently to hospital

Presence of either chest indrawing &/or fast breathing but no general danger sign

Pneumonia
  • Start oral Amoxicillin x 5 days.
  • The child is sent home and assessed after 48 hours.
  • If the child has improved, continue the same treatment.
  • If the child has worsened, refer to a higher center.

No fast breathing, no chest indrawing, no general danger signs

No pneumonia: cough or cold only

Home-based supportive care

Fast Breathing Criteria:

  • < 2 months: > 60/min
  • 2-12 months: > 50/min
  • 1-5 years: > 40/min

General Danger signs:

  1. Convulsions
  2. Lethargy
  3. Inability to drink or breastfeed
  4. Persistent vomiting
  5. Unconsciousness
  6. Stridor in a calm child

Home-based Management of Pneumonia

Management

Description

Give oral antibiotics

Provide antibiotics to treat a possible respiratory infection (Oral Amoxicillin 40-50 mg/kg/day in 2-3 divded doses for 5 days)

Warn of danger signs

Educate parents about specific warning signs to watch out for, such as worsening respiratory distress or persistent high fever

Send the child home

Discharge the child from the hospital and instruct parents to monitor the child's condition and seek prompt medical help if needed

A 5 year old child brought to the hospital with a history of loose stools. The mother says he is irritable and drinks water hastily when given. On examination, eyes are sunken and during the skin pinch test, the skin retracted after a few seconds but not immediately. What is the treatment for the child?

options.label: A
options.text: Administer the first dose of IV antibiotic and immediately refer to a higher center

options.label: B
options.text: Give oral fluids and ask the mother to continue the same and visit again the next day

options.label: C
options.text: Give zinc supplementation and oral rehydration solution only and ask mother to come back if some danger signs develop

options.label: D
options.text: Consider severe dehydration, start intravenous (IV) fluids, IV antibiotics, and refer to a higher centre

questions.correct_answer: D. Consider severe dehydration, start intravenous (IV) fluids, IV antibiotics, and refer to a higher centre
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D- Consider severe dehydration, start intravenous (IV) fluids, IV antibiotics, and refer to a higher centre

Degree of Dehydration

Clinical Features

Management

Mild
  • Slightly increased thirst
  • Normal urine output
  • Normal skin turgor
  • Oral rehydration therapy (ORT) with a solution containing electrolytes and glucose
  • Encourage the child to drink small, frequent amounts of the ORT solution
  • Continue regular feeding if the child is not vomiting or unable to tolerate oral intake

Moderate
  • Increased thirst
  • Decreased urine output
  • Decreased tears
  • Dry mucous membranes
  • Delayed capillary refill (>2 seconds)
  • Oral rehydration therapy (ORT) with a solution containing electrolytes and glucose
  • Administer ORT in larger amounts and more frequently
  • Monitor vital signs (heart rate, blood pressure), urine output, and mental status
  • Consider antiemetic medication if vomiting is present
  • If unable to tolerate oral intake or deteriorating clinical status, consider intravenous fluids

Severe
  • Markedly increased thirst
  • Minimal or no urine output
  • Sunken eyes, lethargy, irritability
  • Cool extremities, mottled or pale skin
  • Altered mental status, decreased consciousness
  • Initiate intravenous fluids with a bolus of isotonic saline or lactated Ringer's solution
  • Administer maintenance intravenous fluids and correct electrolyte imbalances as necessary
  • Monitor vital signs closely, including heart rate, blood pressure, oxygen saturation
  • Address underlying causes, such as infections or other medical conditions
  • Consider transfer to a higher level of care if there are signs of severe or life-threatening dehydration

questions.text: A 5 year old boy presented with hematemesis and was found to have splenomegaly, on examination. There was a past history of exchange transfusion in this child for neonatal jaundice. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B- Portal vein th

Feature

Description

Definition

Partial or complete obstruction of the portal vein, which carries blood from the gastrointestinal tract, spleen, and pancreas to the liver

Etiology
  • Cirrhosis or liver fibrosis
  • Hypercoagulable states (e.g., prothrombine gene mutation)
  • Infections (e.g., abdominal sepsis)
  • Abdominal malignancies

Clinical Presentation
  • Abdominal pain, often in the right upper quadrant
  • Enlarged spleen (splenomegaly)
  • Ascites (fluid accumulation in the abdomen)
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding
  • Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes)
  • Fever and chills
  • Altered mental status (in severe cases)

Diagnostic Evaluation
  • Imaging studies: Doppler ultrasound, computed tomography (CT), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
  • Laboratory tests: Liver function tests, coagulation profile, complete blood count

Management
  • Treatment of underlying cause (e.g., anticoagulation for hypercoagulable states)
  • Symptomatic management: Analgesics for pain relief, diuretics for ascites, management of complications
  • Surgical intervention (in selected cases)

Prognosis
  • The prognosis depends on the underlying cause, extent of thrombosis, and response to treatment.
  • Complications can include portal hypertension, gastrointestinal bleeding, liver failure, and sepsis

Contraceptive Method

Pearl Index (Failure Rate per 100 Woman-Years)

Women with irregular menstrual cycles or acne seeking contraception

Long-term contraception; contraindications to estrogen

Prevention of STIs and contraception

questions.text: A male infant was brought to the emergency pediatric unit with abdominal distention. There was a history of recurrent urinary tract infections. On examination, he was found to have urinary retention. Imaging showed bilateral hydronephrosis. What could be the probable diagnosis of his condition?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B- Posterior urethral valves

Feature

Description

Definition

Abnormal flaps of tissue in the posterior urethra that obstruct the flow of urine in male infants

Etiology

Developmental anomaly during fetal development

Clinical Presentation
  • Urinary tract obstruction symptoms, such as poor urinary stream, dribbling, or difficulty urinating
  • Urinary tract infections (UTIs) with fever, irritability, and poor feeding
  • Enlarged bladder (palpable abdominal mass)
  • Hydronephrosis (swelling of the kidneys due to urine backup)
  • Poor weight gain and growth

Diagnostic Evaluation
  • Voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG): Radiographic imaging to visualize the urinary tract and identify the valves
  • Ultrasound of the kidneys and bladder to assess for hydronephrosis
  • Blood tests: Renal function tests and electrolyte levels

Management
  • Endoscopic valve ablation or fulguration to remove or destroy the obstructing valves
  • Surgical intervention: Valve resection or reconstruction in severe cases
  • Management of urinary tract infections and associated complications

Prognosis
  • The prognosis varies depending on the severity of the obstruction and associated renal damage
  • Early diagnosis and intervention can lead to better outcomes and improved renal function
  • Long-term monitoring and follow-up are necessary to monitor renal function and manage any potential complications

questions.text: In a woman presenting with amenorrhea, headache, blurred vision, and galactorrhea, the appropriate investigation is:
During infancy, what is the most prevalent causative agent of acute bronchiolitis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D- Respiratory syncytial virus

Bronchiolitis

Age Group

Infants between 1 and 6 months, but can affect children up to 2 years old.

Seasonality

Occurs primarily in winter and spring.

Causative Agent
  • Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) (Most common)
  • Others include:
    • Parainfluenza virus (Option B)
    • Adenovirus
    • Influenza virus (Option A)
    • Rarely Mycoplasma pneumoniae.

Risk factors
  • M/c in male infants.
  • Infants exposed to tobacco smoke, not breastfed, or living in crowded conditions.
  • Maternal smoking
  • Older family members/siblings (common source of infection)

Protection
  • IgG3 antibodies (short half-life, limited placental transfer)
  • Breastfeeding provides IgA antibodies.

Pathophysiology
  • Bronchiolar obstruction with edema, mucus and cellular debris.
  • Increased airway resistance during both inspiration and exhalation.
  • Leads to expiratory wheezing, air trapping, lung hyperinflation and possible atelectasis.
  • Hypoxemia due to ventilation-perfusion mismatch.
  • With severe obstructive disease hypercapnia develops.

Clinical Manifestations
  • First develop upper respiratory symptoms: Sneezing and clear rhinorrhea.
  • Fever (±)
  • Diminished appetite
  • Persistent Cough
  • Dyspnea
  • Irritability
  • Respiratory distress
  • Cyanosis.

Physical Examination
  • Prolonged expiratory time
  • Wheezing
  • Increased work of breathing with nasal flaring and retractions
  • Accessory muscles of respiration are working
  • Auscultation: Fine crepitations and rhonchi
  • Faint or inaudible breath sounds in severe disease

IVB

IVC

Distant metastasis, including metastasis to any extra- or intra-abdominal lymph nodes above the renal vessels, lungs, liver, brain, or bone

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy, as shown in the image, presents with fever and painful sores in the mouth, along with a rash on his hand. Which of the following is the causative agent?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B- Coxsackie virus

Hand Foot Mouth Disease (HFMD)

Causative organism

Coxsackie A16 virus, Enterovirus 71

Age group

<5 years

Clinical features
  • Low grade fever, feeling of being unwell, sore throat are commonly observed.
  • Characterized by papulovesicular skin rash commonly on buttocks, knees, elbows and genital area.
  • Ulcers/blisters are also seen in the oral cavity, mostly on the posterior aspect.

Management

  • Resolves on its own in 5-7 days, till then symptomatic and conservative treatment is given.
  • Isolation of affected children at home and promotion of hand hygiene to prevent disease spread is important.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of a 10-year-old boy who was brought for psychiatric evaluation due to intellectual disability and exhibits an IQ of 45? The boy also presents with physical characteristics such as a long face, large ears, and large testes, along with a cardiac murmur. Additionally, there is a history of poor intellectual function in the paternal family.
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C- Fragile X syndrome

Fragile X Syndrome:

Genetic Basis

CGG repeats on FMR-1 (Familial mental retardation) gene on X chromosome

CGG Repeat Numbers
  • Normal population: 5-55 repeats
  • Carriers (premutation): 55-200 repeats
  • Fragile X Syndrome: >200 repeats

Gender Prevalence
  • More common in males (X-Linked Dominant Inheritance)
  • Females mostly carriers

Clinical Features
  • Long face & large ears
  • Large mandible/Prominent jaw
  • High arched palate
  • Hyperextensible joints
  • Mitral valve prolapse
  • Macroorchidism/large testes (seen in adolescent age group)
  • Intellectual disability

Clinical features of female carriers

  • May be associated with premature ovarian failure
  • 10% may have an intellectual disability/low IQ

questions.text: A 22-year-old mother presented with her 2-week-old newborn who had a large tongue and an umbilical hernia. Which of the following investigations has to be done in view of congenital hypothyroidism?

options.label: A
options.text: A fresh blood sample and screen first for TSH levels

options.label: B
options.text: A fresh blood sample and screen first for T4 levels

options.label: C
options.text: A dried blood sample and screen first for TSH levels

options.label: D
options.text: A dried blood sample and screen first for T4 levels

questions.correct_answer: C. A dried blood sample and screen first for TSH levels
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C- A dried blood sample and screen first for TSH levels

Congenital Hypothyroidism

Definition
  • Most common preventable cause of intellectual disability
  • Prevalence of 1 in 2,000 newborns
  • Results from defects in hypothalamic-pituitary axis or thyroid gland
  • Can be congenital or acquired

Etiology
  • Thyroid dysgenesis (75% of cases)
  • Spectrum ranging from agenesis to ectopic thyroid
  • Biosynthetic defects affecting iodine transport, peroxidation, thyroglobulin synthesis
  • Pendred syndrome (associated with decreased intracellular transport of iodine and deafness)
  • Genetic defects associated with TSHR, PAX8, and TSHB genes

Clinical Features

Congenital Signs:

  • Open posterior fontanel
  • Umbilical hernia
  • Delayed neurodevelopment
  • Large tongue

Common Features:

  • Growth retardation
  • Sallow edematous facies
  • Delayed skeletal maturation
  • Delayed dental eruption
  • Delayed puberty
  • Constipation
  • Myopathy and pseudohypertrophy
  • Hypothermia

Screening
  • Dried blood spot (DBS) sample at age 2-4 days
  • Screen first for TSH levels
  • TSH thresholds for treatment:
    • >20 mU/L in first week
    • >10 mU/L between 7-21 days
    • >6 mU/L beyond 21 days

Investigations

Initial Tests:

  • Serum TSH and FT4 levels
  • TSH > 20 mU/L in first week needs evaluation

Further Evaluation:

  • Radionuclide scan
  • Ultrasound of thyroid
  • Children with undetectable thyroid may need testing for:
  • Defects in iodine transport
  • TSH receptor abnormalities
  • TSH blocking antibody

Management
  • Immediate thyroxine replacement after diagnosis
  • Dosage: 10-15 μg/kg/day
  • In central hypothyroidism, cortisol replacement should precede thyroid replacement
  • Monitor FT4 and TSH levels every 2 months in first year
  • Long-term follow-up required
  • Most children require lifelong therapy

Most posterior structure.

Internal spermatic fascia

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient came to the hospital complaining of palpitations. During the examination, a diastolic murmur is detected in the left third intercostal space, along with the presence of a pistol shot sound over the femoral arteries. What is the diagnosis here?
questions.explanation:
Signs of Aortic Regurgitation

Muller Sign

It is a visible systolic pulsation of the uvula

Rosenbach sign

Systolic pulsations of the Liver

Gerhardt's sign

Systolic pulsations of the Spleen

Quincke's sign

Repeatedly alternating blushing and blanching of capillaries in the nail folds upon palpation (Capillary Pulsations)

Landolphi sign

Alternating systolic constriction and diastolic dilatation of pupils

Traube Sign

It is pistol shot sounds that are heard while auscultating over the femoral artery.

Water-Hammer pulse

Strong pulse that rises quickly and then drops off suddenly.

Duroziez Sign

It is a to-and-fro murmur heard while auscultating the femoral artery.

De-Musset sign

The jarring motion of the head with each heartbeat

Blood Pressure
  • Elevated systolic pressure and decreased diastolic pressure result in increased arterial pulse pressure.
  • Atrio-ventricular malformation and Atrio-ventricular ﬁstula also show low diastolic BP due to continuous Korotkoﬀ sounds.
  • Positive Hill’s sign is an abnormal difference in BP in the upper limb and lower limb.

On Palpation
  • Heaving LV impulse is noted, which is displaced laterally and inferiorly
  • Diastolic and Systolic Thrills were noticed at the left lower sternal border and suprasternal notch, respectively.

On Auscultation

  

Heart Sounds
  • A2 is absent
  • In the Bicuspid aortic valve, systolic ejection sound is present
  • Sometimes, A4 is also heard

Murmurs
  • A decrescendo diastolic murmur, best heard when sitting up and leaning forward, is an early diastolic murmur that becomes holo-diastolic as the condition progresses to a severe stage.
  • Musical diastolic murmur is aortic cusp fluttering in the regurgitant flow.
  • Mid-diastolic murmur
  • Austin Flint murmur is a soft, low-pitched, mid- to end-diastolic murmur caused by mitral valve displacement due to AR.
  • Ejection systolic murmur is commonly heard in AR along with AS.
