questions.explanation:
Clinical Features of Left-Sided vs. Right-Sided Congestive Heart Failure (CHF)

Left-Sided Heart Failure

Right-Sided Heart Failure

Causes:

  • Ischemic heart disease (myocardial infarction).
  • Hypertension
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy.
  • Aortic or mitral valve disease.

Causes:

  • Left-sided heart failure (most common cause).
  • Chronic lung diseases (COPD, pulmonary hypertension).
  • Pulmonary embolism.
  • Right ventricular infarction.

In left-sided heart failure, the left ventricle cannot effectively pump blood to the body, leading to a backup of blood into the lungs.

Clinical features:

This primarily results in pulmonary symptoms.

  • Dyspnea
  • Exertional dyspnea).
  • Orthopnea
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea

Pulmonary Congestion:

  • Crackles (rales) heard on auscultation due to fluid in the alveoli.
  • Cough
  • Wheezing (cardiac asthma).
  • Fatigue and Weakness
  • Decreased Exercise Tolerance
  • Limited physical activity due to breathlessness and fatigue.
  • S3 Gallop
  • Cool Extremities: Reduced cardiac output may cause poor peripheral circulation, leading to cold, pale skin.

In right-sided heart failure, the right ventricle fails to pump blood effectively into the pulmonary circulation, leading to systemic venous congestion. It is often secondary to left-sided heart failure or conditions affecting the lungs (cor pulmonale).

Clinical Features:

  • Peripheral Edema
  • Jugular Venous Distension (JVD)
  • Hepatomegaly
  • B/L pitting pedal oedema
  • Kussmaul sign: JVP elevation on inspiration
  • Ascites
  • Nocturia
  • Weight Gain
  • Anorexia and Nausea

 

Pleural fluid Analysis

Light's Criteria

Differentiates transudative from exudative pleural effusions based on LDH and protein levels in pleural fluid.

  • An exudative pleural effusion meets at least one of the following:
    1. Pleural fluid protein/serum protein > 0.5
    2. Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH > 0.6
    3. Pleural fluid LDH exceeds two-thirds of the normal upper limit for serum.
  • ~25% of transudates may be misidentified as exudates.
  • If exudative criteria are met but a transudative condition is suspected, measure protein difference; if >31 g/L (3.1 g/dL), likely transudative.

Identify the tachycardia depicted in the given ECG.
questions.explanation:
Atrial Flutter

Features
  • Atrial flutter is characterized by a large re-entry circuit, usually within the right atrium, encircling the tricuspid annulus originating from the cavotricuspid isthmus.
  • The atrial rate is approximately 300 beats per minute.
  • It is typically associated with 2:1, 3:1, or 4:1 AV block, resulting in ventricular rates of 150, 100, or 75 beats per minute.

ECG Features
  • The ECG shows saw-tooth flutter waves, often referred to as "F-waves."
  • With a 2:1 AV block, flutter waves may be buried in QRS complexes and T waves, making them difficult to identify.

Diagnosis
  • Atrial flutter should be suspected in narrow-complex tachycardia at a rate of 150 beats per minute.
  • Carotid sinus pressure or intravenous adenosine may help reveal flutter waves by temporarily increasing the degree of AV block.

Management

1. Rhythm Control:

  • Acute Management:
    • Hemodynamically Unstable Patients: Synchronized cardioversion.
    • Stable Patients:
      • Electrical cardioversion (if no intracardiac thrombus).
      • Pharmacological cardioversion:
        • Antiarrhythmic drugs:
          • Amiodarone
          • Class IA: Procainamide, Quinidine, Disopyramide
          • Class IC: Flecainide, Propafenone
        • Calcium Channel Blockers: Verapamil, Diltiazem
        • Beta-Blockers: Metoprolol, Carvedilol, Esmolol
  • Long-Term Management:
    • Radiofrequency catheter ablation of the cavotricuspid isthmus.

2. Rate Control:

  • First-Line Agents:
    • Calcium Channel Blockers (e.g., Verapamil, Diltiazem)
    • Beta-blockers (e.g., Metoprolol, Carvedilol, Esmolol)
    • Digoxin (use cautiously due to toxicity).
  • Goal: Heart rate < 110 beats per minute.

3. Anticoagulation:

  • Assess stroke risk using the CHADS2-VASC score:
  • Anticoagulation Recommendations:
    • 2 or more points: Strong recommendation for anticoagulation.
    • 1 point: Consider either aspirin or full anticoagulation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the OPD with palpitation and weight loss. On examination of her legs the following lesion was found which on applying pressure, the indentation does not persist on release. ECG shows sinus rhythm. What is the probable cause of the oedema?
questions.explanation:
Nephrotic Syndrome

Clinical manifestations

Pathophysiology

Proteinuria

The damage to the glomerular filtration barrier leads to increased permeability to proteins.

Odema

Hypoalbuminemia
  • Due to urinary loss of albumin being more than its synthesis by the liver.
  • Muehrcke's lines (linear white lines in the nail bed seen in hypoalbuminemia)

Hyperlipidemia
  • Xanthoma and xanthelasma can be appreciated.

Hypercoagulability

This can be due to factors like:

  • Due to the loss of anticoagulant proteins like Protein C/ Protein S/ Antithrombin III
  • Ferritin deficiency
  • History of factor V Leiden mutation
  • Increased production of procoagulant factors by the liver.

Infections

Loss of immunoglobulins in urine causes hypogammaglobulinemia, increasing susceptibility to infections.

Diagnostic criteria for Nephrotic syndrome

Essential findings
  • Proteinuria of > 3.5 g/day
  • Urine PCR > 2g protein/g of creatinine
  • Hypoalbuminemia - serum Albumin < 2.5 gm%
  • Oedema due to reduced oncotic pressure

Other findings
  • Hypercholesterolemia,
  • Lipiduria
    • Urine microscopy: Oval fat bodies/Maltese cross bodies
  • Low eGFR
  • Hypercoagulability

questions.text: A postoperative cardiac surgery patient developed sudden hypotension, raised central venous pressure, and pulsus paradoxus at the 4 th postoperative hour. The most probable diagnosis is.
questions.explanation:
Cardiac Tamponade

Definition

A condition where the cardiac chambers are compressed by a tense pericardial effusion, limiting cardiac inflow. Fluid accumulation of as little as 200 ml to upwards of 2 L may lead to cardiac tamponade development.

Clinical Features

Beck's triad

  • Jugular Venous Distension: Due to increased central venous pressure. Prominent x descent and an absent y descent.
  • Hypotension: Resulting from impaired cardiac output.
  • Muffled Heart Sounds: Caused by fluid accumulation in the pericardial space, dampening heart sounds.

Other features

Pulsus paradoxus: A drop in systolic BP during inspiration, greater than 10 mm Hg.

Causes of Pulsus paradoxus:

  • Lung Conditions: Acute asthma, COPD, tension pneumothorax, pleural effusion, pulmonary embolism.
  • Heart Conditions: Cardiac tamponade, constrictive pericarditis.

Low-Pressure Cardiac Tamponade

Definition

This occurs when lower pericardial pressure leads to tamponade, often in cases of intravascular fluid depletion (e.g., hypovolemia).

Features

Jugular Venous Distension: Often absent

Pulsus Paradoxus: Rare

Requires a high degree of suspicion due to the absence of typical signs like jugular venous distension and pulsus paradoxus.

questions.explanation:
WERNICKE-KORSAKOFF SYNDROME (CEREBRAL BERI-BERI)

Clinical Manifestations

Wernicke Encephalopathy:

Symptoms: Ophthalmoplegia, nystagmus, cerebellar ataxia, global confusion.

Korsakoff Psychosis:

Symptoms: Anterograde and retrograde amnesia, sensory agnosia, and confabulation. (Option B)

Causes of Thiamine Deficiency in Alcoholics
  • Increased thiamine requirements due to alcohol consumption. Alcohol is a source of empty calories.
  • Inhibition of intestinal thiamine absorption by alcohol.

Metabolic Implications
  • Impaired conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA.
  • Accumulation of pyruvate and lactate in the blood.
  • Potential for life-threatening lactic acidosis.

Progression and Risk Factors
  • Progression from Wernicke encephalopathy to Korsakoff psychosis if untreated.
  • Associated with severely compromised nutritional status, often due to chronic alcoholism.

MRI findings

Symmetrical T2/FLAIR signal increase in the mammillary bodies, dorsomedial thalami, tectal plate, periaqueductal area, and around the third ventricle.

Treatment

Acute Phase (Wernicke Encephalopathy):

  • Intravenous thiamine (100 mg) for 3-7 days is standard; however, higher doses (500 mg TID) may be required if symptoms persist.
  • Glucose should be administered after thiamine to prevent exacerbating symptoms.

Chronic Phase (Korsakoff’s Psychosis):

  • Continue oral thiamine indefinitely, especially in alcohol-dependent patients.
  • Address co-occurring deficiencies, provide nutritional support, and consider rehabilitation or residential care if needed.

A middle-aged man presents with a gradual onset of swallowing difficulties for both solid and liquid foods, persisting for 8 months. The barium swallow test results are presented below. questions.explanation:
Achalasia cardia

Definition

It is a primary motility disorder (Option B ruled out) characterised by the progressive degeneration of ganglion cells in the esophageal wall, which leads to a loss of peristalsis in the lower oesophagus and failure of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax during swallowing

(Option A & D ruled out)

Clinical Features

 
  • Dysphagia: May initially affect liquids more than solids.
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Chest Pain
  • Weight Loss

Investigations:

Esophageal Manometry

Gold Standard: This is the definitive diagnostic test for achalasia. It measures the pressure and pattern of muscle contractions in the esophagus.

  • Elevated resting LES pressure (typically > 45 mmHg).
  • Incomplete LES relaxation.
  • Absence of peristalsis in the esophageal body.
  • Periodic contractions with normal amplitude or high amplitude contractions (type I and II achalasia).

Barium Swallow (Esophagram)

Dilated esophagus with a narrowing at the LES (Bird beak appearance/ Pencil tip appearance/ Rat tail appearance).

 

 

Endoscopy:

Normal mucosa but may show dilated esophagus with possible food debris. It is important to rule out other causes of dysphagia, such as tumours.

questions.explanation:
Types of pneumothoraces:

Type

Cause

Characteristics

Common Treatment

Primary Spontaneous Pneumothorax

Occurs without underlying lung disease
  • Often due to rupture of apical pleural blebs
  • Seen commonly in smokers
  • Simple aspiration
  • Thoracoscopy if recurrent

Secondary Spontaneous Pneumothorax

Associated with pre-existing lung conditions (e.g., COPD)

More life-threatening due to reduced pulmonary reserve
  • Tube thoracostomy
  • Thoracoscopy or pleurodesis if needed
  • Thoracoscopy with stapling of blebs and pleural abrasion if surgery is contraindicated

Traumatic Pneumothorax

Occurs during mechanical ventilation or resuscitation

It can be iatrogenic (from medical procedures)
  • Tube thoracostomy
  • Manage hemopneumothorax with dual chest tubes

Tension Pneumothorax

Results from physical injury (blunt or penetrating)
  • Positive pressure in pleural space
  • Severe cardiovascular compromise

Emergency treatment with large bore needle decompression followed by thoracostomy

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presented to his primary care physician with a 3-month history of increasing urinary frequency without burning and nocturia four times each day. He has limited his fluid consumption and caffeine intake in the evening without much benefit. On prostate examination, the swelling was palpated with a smooth surface, and a firm, non-tender rubber-like consistency was found. The physician thinks of benign prostate hypertrophy. All are characteristic features of benign prostate hypertrophy except:
questions.correct_answer: A. Increased trabeculations in the bladder
questions.explanation:
Benign Prostate Hyperplasia (BPH)

Explanation
  • Age affected: Men over 50 years
  • After 60 years, 50% of men have histological evidence of BPH.
  • Common cause of significant lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) in men: BPH
  • Common cause of bladder outflow obstruction (BOO) in men more than 70 years of age: BPH

Etiopathogenesis
  • Role of hormones in BPH:
    • DHT (Dihydrotestosterone)
      • DHT, derived from testosterone via 5-alpha reductase, binds to androgen receptors in the prostate, promoting cellular proliferation and contributing to prostatic enlargement.
    • Estrogen
      • Estrogen levels increase relative to testosterone in ageing men, influencing prostate growth through the activation of estrogen receptors, particularly ER-α, in the prostatic tissue.
  • Affects both glandular epithelium and connective tissue stroma to variable degrees.

Common site of origin

Submucosal glands of the periurethral transitional zone

Secondary changes in the bladder

It is due to increased force of contraction of detrusor muscles):

  • Collagen deposition
  • Detrusor muscle hyperplasia
  • Detrusor muscle hypertrophy.

Clinical features
  • Obstructive symptoms:
    • Poor flow/stream
    • Hesitancy
    • Intermittency
    • Incomplete voiding-High post-void residual urine
    • Dribbling of urine
  • Irritative symptoms:
    • Frequency
    • Urgency
    • Nocturia

Complications
  • Retention
  • Haematuria
  • Urinary infection
  • Stone formation
  • Hydronephrosis

questions.text: Most common site of peripheral aneurysm?
Which one of the following is absent in cases of massive blood transfusion?
questions.explanation:
Complications of massive blood transfusion

Complication

Cause

Effect

Hypothermia

Transfusion of cold blood (stored at 4°C).

Body temperature drops, leading to impaired clotting mechanisms (coagulopathy), and worsening bleeding.

Coagulopathy

 

 

Dilution of clotting factors and platelets due to transfusion; consumption of clotting factors by ongoing haemorrhage.

Impaired blood clotting, prolonged bleeding time, thrombocytopenia, and increased risk of continued bleeding.

(Option D ruled out)

DIC

(Option A ruled out)

Due to the release of procoagulant substances

Leads to haemorrhage due to depleted hemostatic components, tissue hypoxia, and infarction due to microthrombi, or both.

Citrate Toxicity

Large volumes of transfused blood contain citrate, which binds to calcium.

Hypocalcemia leads to muscle cramps, seizures, and cardiac arrhythmias.

Hypocalcemia

 
  • Packed red blood cells (PRBCs) and other blood products are preserved with citrate, an anticoagulant.
  • Citrate binds to ionised calcium (Ca²⁺) in the recipient's blood, reducing the free calcium level - hypocalcemia

Presents as muscle spasms, cardiac arrhythmias, and decreased myocardial contractility

Hyperkalemia

 

Potassium leaks from stored red blood cells into plasma during storage.

Elevated potassium levels (hyperkalemia) can cause cardiac arrhythmias, potentially leading to cardiac arrest.

Hypokalemia

 

Potassium may shift intracellularly once transfused red blood cells are metabolically revived.

Hypokalemia causes muscle weakness, paralysis, and cardiac arrhythmias.

Metabolic Alkalosis

Rapid metabolism of citrate into bicarbonate.

Increased pH (alkalosis) can lead to muscle twitching, irritability, and impaired oxygen release from haemoglobin.

Metabolic Acidosis

Inadequate tissue perfusion leads to lactic acid accumulation.

Lowered blood pH (acidosis) leads to confusion, fatigue, rapid breathing, and worsened cardiovascular function.

Transfusion Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI)

Antibodies in transfused blood activate the recipient's immune response, causing inflammation and fluid buildup in the lungs.

Non-cardiogenic pulmonary oedema, presenting as acute respiratory distress with hypoxia within 6 hours of transfusion.

Transfusion Associated Circulatory Overload (TACO)

Volume of transfused blood exceeds the patient’s capacity to manage, leading to fluid overload.

Pulmonary oedema, shortness of breath, hypertension, and signs of heart failure.

Iron Overload

Repeated transfusions lead to excessive accumulation of iron.

Iron deposits in organs (e.g., liver, heart, pancreas), lead to organ damage and failure over time.

Hemolytic Reactions

ABO or Rh incompatibility.

Rapid destruction of red blood cells (hemolysis), causes fever, chills, hemoglobinuria, and potentially acute renal failure or shock.

Allergic Reactions

Reaction to proteins in transfused blood products.

Symptoms range from mild itching, rash, or hives to severe anaphylaxis (airway constriction, low blood pressure, shock).

Bacterial Contamination

Blood products are contaminated during collection or storage.

Sepsis, characterized by fever, chills, low blood pressure, and possibly septic shock.

Febrile transfusion reaction

(Option B ruled out)

It is a non-hemolytic condition that is not completely understood but is believed to be caused by residual white blood cells in the blood unit or cytokines that accumulate during storage.

Fever, rigour, chills

questions.text: In a hypotensive patient with a head injury, which of the subsequent fluids should be avoided?
The likely diagnosis for a newborn infant presenting with signs of intestinal obstruction, as indicated by the x-ray image and CT abdomen showing an annular pancreas, is:
questions.explanation:
Duodenal Atresia

Pathophysiology
  • Failed recanalisation of intestinal lumen during gestation

Associated Conditions
  • Prematurity (50%)
  • Congenital anomalies (heart disease, malrotation, annular pancreas, etc.)
  • Chromosomal abnormalities (e.g., trisomy 21)

Clinical Presentation
  • Bilious vomiting without abdominal distention.
  • Symptoms typically present within the first few days of life.

Diagnosis
  • Confirmed by the double bubble sign on the abdominal X-ray and prenatal ultrasonography.

Treatment
  • Initial: Nasogastric decompression and IV fluids
  • Definitive: Surgical repair (Duodenoduodenostomy)
  • Postoperative care: Gastrostomy tube, nutritional support

questions.text: A factory worker working in a plastic pipe factory presented to the OPD with weight loss and right upper quadrant abdominal pain for 6 months duration. He had hepatomegaly. Further investigation revealed that most of the liver was replaced by a hemorrhagic tumour with extensive necrosis. What can be the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.explanation:
Hepatic Angiosarcoma

Definition
  • It is a high-grade vascular malignancy that arises from the endothelial cells lining blood vessels or lymphatic channels.
  • It is the most common sarcoma arising in the liver, especially in those with significant exposure to Vinyl chloride.

Common in

Men and elderly

Risk Factors
  • Arsenic,
  • Radiation,
  • Thorium dioxide (Thorotrast)

Metastasis
  • It can spread through lymphatic and hematogenous routes, but due to the tumour's vascular nature, hematogenous spread (via blood vessels) is more common.
  • The liver and lungs are common sites of metastasis, reflecting the tumour's aggressive nature

Clinical presentation

It presents as a red-brown, indurated, and ulcerated skin lesion.

questions.text: A patient who underwent Nissen’s fundoplication was seen in the ward during evening rounds. He is asymptomatic at present and has stable vitals. What is the next line of management for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Nasogastric tube to prevent gas bloat syndrome

options.label: B
options.text: Insert chest tube to prevent pneumothorax

questions.explanation:
Management of GERD

Lifestyle Changes
  • Elevate the head of the bed
  • Avoid lying down after meals
  • Quit smoking

Medical management
  • Antacids: Neutralize stomach acid
  • H2-receptor antagonists: Ranitidine, Famotidine
  • Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs): Omeprazole, Esomeprazole

Surgical management

Antireflux operation: 3 components

  • Restoration of the intra-abdominal segment of the esophagus
  • Crural repair
  • Reinforcement of the LES by the upper stomach or prosthesis.

Fundoplication: A surgical procedure to wrap the top of the stomach around the lower oesophagus to strengthen the sphincter.

  • Complete fundoplication (Nissen)
  • Partial fundoplication: Posteriorly (Toupet) or Anteriorly(Dor, Watson) has few short-term side effects but has a higher long-term failure rate.
  • Transoral Incisionless Fundoplication (TIF): An endoscopic procedure performed through the mouth but may be less effective for severe GERD and not suitable for all patients.
  • Magnetic Sphincter Augmentation (LINX Device): Involves implanting a ring of magnetic beads around the lower oesophagal sphincter to enhance its function and prevent reflux.

questions.explanation:
Rectal exam findings on external and internal inspection:

External Inspection

Internal Inspection

  • Genital warts

  • Rectal carcinoma
  • Rectal polyps
  • Tenderness with prostatitis or acute appendicitis
  • Malignant or inflammatory conditions of the peritoneum with anterior palpation

questions.text: Identify the incision marked as B
questions.explanation:
Types of Incisions used for appendicectomy

Name of the incision

Incision area

Type of incision

McBurney's incision

(A in the image)
  • Centered on McBurney's point, perpendicular to the umbilical ASIS line
  • Junction of lateral 1/3 from umbilicus & medial 2/3 from ASIS
  • McBurney's point corresponds to the base of the appendix
  • Muscle splitting incision
  • Aka Grid iron incision / McArthur incision (Option A ruled out)

Lanz incision

(B in the image)

Placed transversely 2 cm below the umbilicus on the line joining the midpoint of the clavicle to the midpoint of the inguinal ligament
  • Muscle splitting incision
  • Cosmetically better incision
  • Aka Modified McBurney's incision / Rocky Davis incision (Option D ruled out) / Bikini incision (good cosmetic appearance)

Rutherford-Morrison incision

(C in the image)

(Option C ruled out)

 
  • Extension of McBurney's incision for retrocecal appendicitis.
  • Upward & laterally by cutting the conjoint tendon.
  • Muscle cutting incision
  • Preferred for retrocecal appendix

questions.text: Which of the following statements about carcinoid tumours in the appendix is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Size appears to be the best predictor of malignant behaviour and metastatic potential

options.label: B
options.text: Arise from Kulchitsky cells of the crypts of Leiberkuhn

options.label: C
options.text: Most common location is the base of the appendix

options.label: D
options.text: Most common tumor of the appendix

questions.correct_answer: C. Most common location is the base of the appendix
questions.explanation:
Carcinoid tumor of the appendix (aka Argentaffinoma)

Definition

(Options A & D ruled out)
  • They are neuroendocrine tumours that originate from the enterochromaffin cells (also known as Kulchitsky cells) of the crypts of Lieberkuhn.
  • They are considered the most common tumours of the appendix.

MC Location

Tip of the appendix

Clinical Presentation

Mostly discovered incidentally during surgery

Larger tumours may cause abdominal pain, flushing, and diarrhoea due to hormone secretion

Hormone Secretion

Secretes serotonin and other vasoactive substances.

Risk of Metastasis

(Option A ruled out)
  • Low for tumours <2 cm
  • Higher for tumours>2 cm

Diagnosis

Confirmed by histopathological examination

Treatment
  • <2 cm: Appendectomy
  • >2 cm: Right hemicolectomy

questions.text: A young sheep farmer presents to the OPD with pain in the right upper part of the abdomen. Upon examination, there was tenderness and enlargement of the liver. Blood investigations show eosinophilia, elevated liver enzymes, and abdominal ultrasound, as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Hydatid cyst

Causative agent

Echinococcus granulosus

Commonly Affected Organs
  • Liver (most common site, about 60-70% of cases)
  • Lungs (second most common site)
  • Other organs (rare but possible): Brain, spleen, kidneys, bones, and peritoneum

Clinical Features

Asymptomatic Phase: Common due to slow cyst growth.

Symptomatic Phase:

  • Liver Involvement: Mostly right lobe; Abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, obstructive jaundice, portal hypertension.
  • Lung Involvement: Cough, chest pain, dyspnea, hemoptysis, pneumothorax.

Investigations

Imaging Studies:

  • USG is the first-line imaging modality, particularly for liver involvement.
    • Features: Echinococcal cyst wall shows double echogenic lines separated by a hypoechoic layer (double contour)
  • CT Scan
  • MRI

Serological Tests:

  • ELISA
  • Immunoblotting

Other tests:

  • Casoni Intradermal Test
  • ARC5 Immunoelectrophoresis

WHO Classification of Hydatid cyst

Classification

Cyst Type

Ultrasound Findings

CL

Unilocular Cyst

Cystic lesion and no visible cyst wall

CE1

Simple Active Cyst

Double-line sign; well-defined anechoic cyst

CE2

Multivesicular Cyst

Honeycomb appearance: Visible cyst wall and internal septations

CE3

Transitional Cyst

Have detached laminar membranes or may be partially collapsed and floating within the cyst cavity (Water-lily sign)

CE4

Inactive Cyst

Non-homogenous mass

CE5

Inactive Cyst

Cyst with a thick calcified wall

questions.text: A car driver was brought into the A & E following a RTA with complaints of breathlessness. On examination, his vitals are PR-112/min, BP-100/70, SpO2-90 %, and there is extensive bruising on his chest. What is the management of this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Internal operative fixation of the fracture’s segments

questions.explanation:
Flail chest

Definition
  • It occurs when three or more consecutive ribs are fractured in at least two places, creating a flail segment that moves independently.
  • It exhibits paradoxical chest movement (inwards during inhalation & outwards during exhalation)

Clinical features
  • Hypoventilation: Reduced lung ventilation leads to low oxygen and high CO₂ levels.
  • Mediastinal Flutter: Abnormal mediastinal movement risks sudden cardiac arrest.
  • Pendular Air Movement: Inefficient air exchange between lungs.

Complications
  • Hemothorax: Blood in the chest cavity.
  • Pneumothorax: Air in the chest cavity.

Management
  • Ventilation Support:
    • Oxygen supplementation and Analgesics- Initial management
    • IPPV is the preferred TOC.
    • Tracheostomy if support exceeds 10 days.
  • Injury Management:
    • Intercostal Tube Drainage: Removes air/fluids from the pleural space.
    • Rib Fixation: Stabilises the chest wall.
  • Supportive Care:
    • Blood Transfusions: For blood loss.
    • IV Fluids: For hydration.
    • Antibiotics: To prevent infection.
    • Medications: Bronchodilators and steroids.
  • Thoracotomy:
    • Considered in severe cases

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents to OPD with a low backache. His PSA level is 100 ng/ml. Which of the following drugs is indicated for treatment?

questions.text: A patient underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy for cholelithiasis. A picture of the resected gall bladder is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Gall bladder carcinoma

Risk factors
  • Gallstones, (The risk of developing carcinoma in gallstone disease is 7-10 times higher than in the general population)
  • Porcelain gallbladder,
  • PSC,
  • Abnormal pancreatic-biliary junction

Presentation
  • Often indistinguishable from benign gallbladder diseases
  • Symptoms include:
    • Biliary colic
    • Cholecystitis (especially in older individuals)
    • Jaundice (late-stage)
    • Loss of appetite (late-stage)
    • Palpable mass (late-stage)

Lab investigation
  • Non-specific indicators:
    • Anemia
    • Leukocytosis
    • Slight increase in transaminases
  • Tumor markers:
    • Elevated CA19-9
    • Elevated carcinoembryonic antigen (in ~80% of patients)

Diagnosis
  • Ultrasonography (USG): Initial diagnosis
  • CT Scans: Thorax, abdomen, and pelvis for confirmation and staging
  • MRI/MRCP: For accurate preoperative staging
  • PET Scans: To identify metastatic disease

Staging & Biopsy
  • Preoperative Staging: Crucial to assess local disease extent and rule out distant metastases
  • Percutaneous Biopsy: Guided by radiological imaging for unresectable tumours
  • Laparoscopic Examination: Detects peritoneal or liver metastases that preclude surgery

questions.text: A 25-year-old morbidly obese male patient presented with complaints of severe abdominal pain and urinary disturbances. His urine microscopy shows the following type of crystals, and an ultrasound of the kidney revealed a renal stone of size 2.5 cm. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.explanation:
Management of renal stones

Medical management

Surgical Management
  • Analgesics like diclofenac, ketorolac, tramadol
  • Fluid therapy: IVF (intravenous fluids) are administered to prevent dehydration
  • Alpha 1 blocker: Tamsulosin (relaxes ureter and expels the stone).
  • Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL): Indicated if the size of the calculi <2 cm. (Contraindicated in pregnancy and bleeding diathesis). (Option A ruled out)
  • PCNL (Percutaneous nephrolithotomy): If the size is >2 cm. (Option B)
  • Ureteroscopy
  • Retrograde intrarenal surgery
  • Pyelolithotomy and nephrolithotomy (rarely used).

questions.text: The most common type of gastric sarcoma:
questions.explanation:
Gastrointestinal stromal tumour (GIST)

Mutations
  • Most common- c-KIT/CD117
  • Others:
    • PDGFR- beta
    • Succinate dehydrogenase (SDH)- Small baby( Pediatric GIST)

Mechanism

KIT (c-kit) is a proto-oncogene encoding a receptor tyrosine kinase. Mutations result in constant activation of KIT signalling, driving tumour growth and survival.

Common Locations
  • Stomach: 60-70% of cases.
  • Small Intestine: 20-30%.
  • Other Areas: Colon, rectum, and oesophagus (less common).

Treatment
  • Tyrosine Kinase inhibitors - Imatinib
  • Surgical management

questions.text: According to Weigert Meyer’s rule of duplication of the ureter, the lower pole ureter in the urinary bladder is:

questions.correct_answer: A. Lateral and cephalad to the upper pole ureter

questions.text: A 35-year-old man suffered a blow on a distended bladder ,following which he developed sudden severe pain in the hypogastrium associated with syncope. Later on, as the pain subsided, the abdomen began to distend. However, he had no desire to micturate. Which among the following is true regarding his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: This is a typical case of extraperitoneal bladder rupture

options.label: B
options.text: MRI is the ideal investigation to diagnose bladder rupture

options.label: C
options.text: Repair is done by suturing edges with single-layer 2/0 absorbable suture

options.label: D
options.text: Laparoscopic method is avoided as it can be done only on laparotomy

questions.correct_answer: A. This is a typical case of extraperitoneal bladder rupture
questions.explanation:
Extra peritoneal bladder rupture

Definition

It occurs when the bladder wall is disrupted, but the peritoneal lining remains intact, often due to trauma.

Investigations

(Option B ruled out)
  • CT cystography reveals characteristic features like a flame-shaped appearance, pear sign & teardrop appearance.
  • Retrograde cystography is the imaging modality of choice for diagnosing bladder ruptures, including extraperitoneal injuries.
  • Extravasation of contrast limited to the perivesical space is a key finding that helps differentiate extraperitoneal from intraperitoneal ruptures, where contrast would outline bowel loops.

Management
  • Initial management:
    • Urethral catheterisation with free bladder drainage for 10-14 days.
    • Followed by a cystogram to confirm healing before catheter removal.
  • If the injury is iatrogenic:
    • Repair during the same procedure (open or laparoscopic).
    • Repair done in two layers using 2/0 vicryl absorbable sutures (Option C ruled out)
  • Bladder injury with pelvic fracture:
    • The bladder should be repaired at the same time during the surgery for pelvic fracture.
    • Immediate surgical repair is indeed indicated in cases where there are complicating factors like intravesical bone spicules, bladder neck injuries, or associated vaginal or rectal lacerations.
    • Laparoscopy can be used in the management of bladder rupture, particularly in cases where less invasive approaches are preferred (Option D ruled out).

questions.text: An 11-month-old boy had a recent urinary tract infection that was resolved with antibiotics. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination revealed an empty scrotum on the right side with normal left testis. However, a mass was palpable on the right inguinal canal. The USG revealed the right testicle under the subcutaneous fat near the right inguinal canal, as shown in the image below. What is the next best step in management?
questions.explanation:
Undescended Testis (Cryptorchidism)

Definition

It is a condition where one or both testes fail to descend into the scrotum from the abdomen.

Locations
  • Inguinal/Palpable undescended testis: 80%
  • Abdominal/Non-Palpable undescended testis: 20%

Diagnosis
  • Palpable undescended testis: Inguinal exploration. (Option D)
  • Non-Palpable undescended testis: Diagnostic laparoscopy. (Option B ruled out)
  • Imaging: Ultrasound or MRI may be utilised to locate the testis.

Treatment

Surgical Repositioning (Orchidopexy): Usually performed when the child is between 6-12 months old. (Option C ruled out)

 

Types of Orchidopexy

  • Ombridannes
  • Keetley-Torek
  • Stephen-Fowler
  • Ladd & Gross

questions.text: A 50-year-old lady presented with a 1.5 cm pigmented lesion on her face that was growing rapidly in size and associated with itching. The lesion is shown below. Which of the following is likely the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Malignant melanoma

Definition

Melanoma is a malignant tumour arising from melanocytes at the epidermal-dermal junction. Though it is a rare skin cancer, it has a high mortality rate. It presents as a pigmented lesion that enlarges, ulcerates, or bleeds.

Risk factors
  • Positive family history.
  • Fair skin.
  • Genetics: CDKN2A (chromosome 9p21), MC1R, and TYR genes.
  • Nevus:
    • Congenital melanocytic nevi.
    • Junctional nevi.
    • Atypical nevi.
    • Dysplastic nevi.

Diagnostic criteria

(Pneumonic: ABCDE)

  • Asymmetry: Irregular shapes.
  • Border: Irregular.
  • Colour: Various colours present or uneven distribution.
  • Diameter: > 6 mm.
  • Evolution: Changes in lesion over time (size, shape, itching, or bleeding)

Investigations
  • Clinical examination.
  • Dermoscopy.
  • Biopsy.
  • Immunohistochemistry: The markers are S-100, HMB-45 (the most specific), Melan-A (MART-1), and MITF.
  • CT scan.

Management
  • Wide local excision (with margins measured before excision and determined by Breslow depth, sentinel lymph node biopsy indicated for tumours with a depth of >1.0 mm).
  • If the tumour is aggressive:
    • Immunotherapy.
    • Chemotherapy.
    • Targeted therapy.
  • Interferon-𝛼 is the only adjuvant treatment that has documented beneficial effects on overall survival.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with a lesion over his left ear. It slowly grew in size over the past 3 months, and he is a chronic smoker with 20 pack years. Vitals are within normal limits, and his physical examination is otherwise unremarkable. The histopathologic evaluation shows keratin pearls. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Squamous cell carcinoma

Definition

It is a type of skin cancer that arises from the squamous cells, which are the flat cells found in the epidermis, mucous membranes & tissues lining your organs. It is the second most common type of skin cancer after basal cell carcinoma.

Risk factors
  • High sunlight exposure
  • Arsenic exposure.
  • Immunosuppression (organ transplant, HIV)
  • Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
  • Human papilloma virus.

Presentation

It commonly presents as papules, nodules, or plaques with induration and signs of photodamage like crusting and scaling.

Diagnosis

It involves physical examination and biopsy

Histopathology

Reveals characteristic keratin pearls.

Treatment
  • Primary treatment involves wide surgical excision with margins.
  • Mohs micrographic surgery (MMS) aids in intraoperative histopathological examination.
  • Advanced cases may require radiation or chemotherapy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about ranula is FALSE?

options.label: C
options.text: Bluish, translucent cystic swelling on the floor of the mouth

options.label: D
options.text: Marsupialization or excision is the treatment

questions.correct_answer: B. Arises from submandibular salivary gland
questions.explanation:
Ranula

Definition

(Options A & C ruled out)
  • Ranulas are a type of extravasation mucocele, caused by the rupture of the main duct or obstructed acini of the sublingual gland.
  • They appear as bluish, translucent, cystic swelling on the floor of the mouth and resemble the belly of a frog.

Location
  • Commonly found in the anterior floor of the mouth.
  • When it extends through the mylohyoid muscle, it presents as a submental swelling known as a "plunging ranula."

Symptoms

Typically soft, fluctuant, and painless unless infected.

Diagnosis
  • Confirmed through Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)
  • Ultrasound
  • Aspiration of thick, sticky saliva differentiates it from a lymphangioma.

Treatment

(Option D ruled out)
  • Excision of the sublingual gland is preferred.
  • Incision, drainage, and marsupialisation have low success rates. Although marsupialisation is often adequate, it has a higher recurrence rate compared to sublingual gland excision.
  • OK-432 injection
  • Botulinum toxin injections

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a patient who is taking steroids for psoriasis and is experiencing a low-grade fever only at night, weight loss, and an ulcer on her neck with undermined edges, as depicted in the provided image?
questions.explanation:
Lymph Node TB (Tuberculous Lymphadenitis)

Most common extrapulmonary TB presentation.

Risk Groups

HIV-positive individuals, Immunosuppressive individuals, children, and non-Caucasian women.

Causative Organism

Previously M. bovis; now mainly M. tuberculosis.

Clinical Presentation
  • Painless swelling in lymph nodes, usually posterior cervical or supraclavicular (historically called scrofula).
  • Early disease: Discrete nodes
  • Advanced disease: Matted, nontender mass, possible fistula draining caseous material.
  • Pulmonary disease in <50% of cases.
  • Systemic symptoms are uncommon except in HIV-positive patients.
  • Non-specific reaction → Matting → Cold Abscess → Collar stud abscess → Sinus formation

Diagnosis
  • Fine-needle aspiration biopsy (80% yield) or surgical excision biopsy.
  • Granulomatous lesions may or may not contain AFBs.
  • Cultures are positive in 70–80% of cases.
  • HIV-positive patients: Poorly organised or absent granulomas; higher bacterial loads increase diagnostic yield.

Differential Diagnosis
  • Infectious diseases
  • Lymphomas
  • Metastatic carcinomas
  • Rare disorders: Kikuchi’s disease, Kimura’s disease, Castleman’s disease.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for the unconscious patient brought to the casualty department following a road accident, as depicted in the provided CT scan image?

Types of brain haemorrhage

Type

CT Findings

Mechanism

Epidural or Extradural Hematoma

(Option A ruled out)
  • Biconvex/lentiform shape

  • Cross-dural venous sinuses
  • Hyperdense
  • Usually unilateral

 
  • Typically, meningeal artery injury (especially middle meningeal)
  • High-velocity trauma
  • Young patient
  • Always traumatic

Subdural Hematoma
  • Crescent-shaped
  • Crosses suture lines
  • Can be bilateral
  • Don't cross dural venous sinuses
  • Follows brain surface
  • Bridging vein tears
  • Can be Traumatic or non-traumatic
  • Elderly patients
  • Extent of brain injury more in SDH than in EDH

Intraparenchymal Hematoma

(Option C ruled out)
  • Irregular shape within brain tissue
  • May have surrounding oedema

Direct tissue damage or coagulopathy

Subarachnoid Haemorrhage

(Option D ruled out)
  • Blood in sulci/cisterns
  • Follows CSF spaces

Trauma or aneurysm rupture

options.label: B

questions.correct_answer: B. Most common site is lower lip
questions.explanation:
Feature

Description

Cause

Blockage or damage to the duct system of the salivary gland leads to cyst formation.

Location

Major salivary glands (parotid, submandibular, and sublingual glands) for major retention cysts.

Minor Salivary Glands

Most often found on the lower lip, buccal mucosa, or palate for minor salivary glands.

Treatment

Surgical excision is the standard treatment to remove the cyst and prevent recurrence.

Diagnosis

Clinical examination and ultrasound or sialography for confirmation.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about pterygium?

options.label: C
options.text: Conjunctival invasion making a flap over cornea

questions.correct_answer: C. Conjunctival invasion making a flap over cornea
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Conjunctival invasion making a flap over cornea

Pterygium/Surfer’s eye

 

 

 

 

 

 

Definition

Pterygium is a triangular encroachment of vascularized granulation tissue covered by conjunctiva in the interpalpebral area.

  • Parts: Cap, head, neck, body
  • Degenerative process

 

Aetiology

  • Common in dry, sunny climates with sandy soils
  • Ultraviolet light is a probable factor
  • Usually elderly persons

 

 

 

 

 

Pathology

Histology shows collagenous degenerative changes in the vascularized subepithelial stroma.

 

 

Pathogenesis

  • Degenerative subconjunctival proliferation
  • Granulation tissue proliferates as avascularized tissue encroaches on the cornea.
  • Destroys the superficial layers of the stroma and Bowman’s membrane

 

 

 

Symptoms

  • Frequently follows a pinguecula
  • Often bilateral
  • Usually on the nasal side
  • Impairment of vision due to:
    • Progression into the pupillary area of the cornea
    • Induced astigmatism by corneal flattening in the axis of pterygium
  • Progressive pterygium: thick and vascular
  • Regressive pterygium: thin, pale, and atrophic
  • Ceases to grow but never disappears
  • A probe can be passed under the lesion
  • Can present as inflammed pterygium

Signs

  • A probe cannot be passed under the lesion
  • Fusch’s spots/Islets of Vogt: small discrete whitish flecks made of pterygial epithelial cells seen in progressive pterygium and are also called the cap of the pterygium.
  • Stocker line: linear epithelial iron deposition, seen in regressive pterygium.

 

 

 

Management

  • Best left alone

Medical treatment:

  • Tear substitutes for small regressive pterygium with dry eye
  • Topical steroids for associated inflammation
  • Protection from UV rays with sunglasses

Surgical excision for:

  • Progression of lesion towards the pupillary area causing excessive astigmatism and visual impairment
  • Restricted ocular movements
  • Disfiguring
  • Diplopia

 

 

Procedures
  • Bare sclera technique:
    • The pterygium is excised from the cornea and conjunctiva, leaving a bare sclera
    • Associated with a high recurrence rate
  • Autoconjunctival graft
    • A piece of limbal conjunctival tissue from the same or the other eye or
    • An amniotic membrane graft is used to cover the bare sclera
    • Sutured at the limbus to cover the defect
  • Surgical excision with lamellar keratectomy and lamellar keratoplasty for deeply infiltrating recurrent recalcitrant pterygia
  • Old methods (not used now):
    • McRaynold’s operation
    • Postoperative use of beta irradiations

 

Post-operative therapy and care
  • Prevent recurrence:
    • Mitomycin C 0.02% drops
    • Complications like scleral necrosis, cataracts, and iritis

Pseudopterygium

Definition

  • Pterygium like lesion
  • Due to cicatrizing conjunctival inflammatory overgrowth

 

 

Aetiology

  • Seen at any age
  • Caused by
    • Trauma
    • Chronic conjunctivitis
    • Thermochemical burn

 

Symptoms

  • Non-progressive
  • Can be at any quadrant of the corneal limbus
  • Located away from the horizontal
  • Attached to the cornea due to scar tissue
  • Adhered to the adjacent lid
  • Always stationary

Signs

  • A probe can be passed under the neck.

questions.text: What is the average degree of hypermetropia in a newborn?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - +2.5 D

Type of Hypermetropia

Cause

Axial Hypermetropia

Shortening of the eyeball's axial length. Commonest form.

Curvatural Hypermetropia

Flatter curvature of the cornea, lens, or both.

Index Hypermetropia

Decreased refractive index of the lens, usually due to cortical sclerosis in old age or in treated diabetics.

Positional Hypermetropia

Posterior displacement of the crystalline lens.

Aphakia

Absence of the crystalline lens, either congenital or acquired (e.g., after surgery), leads to high hypermetropia.

Consecutive Hypermetropia

Overcorrected myopia after refractive surgery (e.g., LASIK, ICL) or underpowered intraocular lens (IOL) after cataract surgery.
